title: Attention as Binding: A Vector-Symbolic Perspective on Transformer Reasoning
comment: 12 pages with references. Submitted to 'Logical and Symbolic Reasoning in Language Models @ AAAI 2026' conference and is under review
summary: Transformer-based language models display impressive reasoning-like behavior, yet remain brittle on tasks that require stable symbolic manipulation. This paper develops a unified perspective on these phenomena by interpreting self-attention and residual streams as implementing an approximate Vector Symbolic Architecture (VSA). In this view, queries and keys define role spaces, values encode fillers, attention weights perform soft unbinding, and residual connections realize superposition of many bound structures. We use this algebraic lens to relate transformer internals to chain-of-thought traces, program-based reasoning, and memory-augmented tool use, and to explain characteristic failure modes such as variable confusion and inconsistency across logically related prompts. Building on this perspective, we propose VSA-inspired architectural biases, including explicit binding/unbinding heads and hyperdimensional memory layers, and training objectives that promote role-filler separation and robust superposition. Finally, we outline metrics for measuring "VSA-likeness" and logical compositionality, and pose theoretical and architectural open problems. Overall, the paper argues that viewing attention as soft vector-symbolic computation offers a principled route toward more interpretable and logically reliable reasoning systems.

AI.tldr: The paper interprets transformer self-attention and residual streams as an approximate Vector Symbolic Architecture (VSA), using this lens to explain reasoning behavior and failures, and to propose VSA-inspired architectural and training improvements for more reliable symbolic reasoning.
AI.motivation: Transformer LMs show emergent reasoning-like behavior but fail on tasks needing systematic symbolic manipulation and logical consistency. There is a need for a principled, algebraic perspective that connects transformer internals to symbolic reasoning, explains common failure modes, and guides the design of architectures that reason more robustly and interpretably.
AI.method: Conceptually reinterpret components of transformers within the framework of Vector Symbolic Architectures: treat queries/keys as defining role spaces, values as fillers, attention as soft unbinding, and residual connections as superposition of bindings. Use this algebraic mapping to analyze chain-of-thought traces, program-like reasoning, and tool-use behavior. Propose concrete architectural biases (binding/unbinding heads, hyperdimensional memory) and training objectives to enforce role-filler separation and stable superposition, and define metrics for "VSA-likeness" and logical compositionality.
AI.result: The authors provide a unified algebraic view that links transformer attention mechanics to vector-symbolic computation, showing how this explains phenomena such as variable confusion and inconsistencies across logically related prompts. They introduce candidate architectural modules and training strategies inspired by VSA principles, and sketch quantitative metrics to assess how closely a model’s internals and behavior adhere to VSA-style structure and logical compositionality.
AI.conclusion: Transformers can be fruitfully understood as approximate VSAs, where attention and residual streams implement soft vector-symbolic binding, unbinding, and superposition. This perspective helps explain both their reasoning capabilities and characteristic brittleness, and suggests new architectural biases, objectives, and evaluation metrics aimed at building more interpretable and logically reliable reasoning systems.

title: GR-Agent: Adaptive Graph Reasoning Agent under Incomplete Knowledge
summary: Large language models (LLMs) achieve strong results on knowledge graph question answering (KGQA), but most benchmarks assume complete knowledge graphs (KGs) where direct supporting triples exist. This reduces evaluation to shallow retrieval and overlooks the reality of incomplete KGs, where many facts are missing and answers must be inferred from existing facts. We bridge this gap by proposing a methodology for constructing benchmarks under KG incompleteness, which removes direct supporting triples while ensuring that alternative reasoning paths required to infer the answer remain. Experiments on benchmarks constructed using our methodology show that existing methods suffer consistent performance degradation under incompleteness, highlighting their limited reasoning ability. To overcome this limitation, we present the Adaptive Graph Reasoning Agent (GR-Agent). It first constructs an interactive environment from the KG, and then formalizes KGQA as agent environment interaction within this environment. GR-Agent operates over an action space comprising graph reasoning tools and maintains a memory of potential supporting reasoning evidence, including relevant relations and reasoning paths. Extensive experiments demonstrate that GR-Agent outperforms non-training baselines and performs comparably to training-based methods under both complete and incomplete settings.

AI.tldr: They build KGQA benchmarks that simulate incomplete knowledge graphs and propose an agent-based reasoning method (GR-Agent) that better handles such incompleteness.
AI.motivation: Existing KGQA benchmarks mostly assume complete knowledge graphs, so answering is often shallow retrieval instead of genuine reasoning, and they don’t reflect real-world KG incompleteness where many facts are missing.
AI.method: They propose a benchmark construction methodology that removes direct supporting triples while preserving alternative reasoning paths, and introduce GR-Agent, an adaptive graph reasoning agent that treats KGQA as interaction in an environment built from the KG, using graph-reasoning actions and a memory of candidate evidence and reasoning paths.
AI.result: On benchmarks built with their incompleteness methodology, prior methods’ performance drops substantially, while GR-Agent outperforms non-training baselines and matches training-based methods on both complete and incomplete KGs.
AI.conclusion: Benchmarking under KG incompleteness reveals the limited reasoning of existing KGQA methods; their GR-Agent, which performs adaptive multi-step graph reasoning in an interactive environment, is more robust to missing facts and maintains strong performance across both complete and incomplete KG settings.

title: IaC Generation with LLMs: An Error Taxonomy and A Study on Configuration Knowledge Injection
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) currently exhibit low success rates in generating correct and intent-aligned Infrastructure as Code (IaC). This research investigated methods to improve LLM-based IaC generation, specifically for Terraform, by systematically injecting structured configuration knowledge. To facilitate this, an existing IaC-Eval benchmark was significantly enhanced with cloud emulation and automated error analysis. Additionally, a novel error taxonomy for LLM-assisted IaC code generation was developed. A series of knowledge injection techniques was implemented and evaluated, progressing from Naive Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to more sophisticated Graph RAG approaches. These included semantic enrichment of graph components and modeling inter-resource dependencies. Experimental results demonstrated that while baseline LLM performance was poor (27.1% overall success), injecting structured configuration knowledge increased technical validation success to 75.3% and overall success to 62.6%. Despite these gains in technical correctness, intent alignment plateaued, revealing a "Correctness-Congruence Gap" where LLMs can become proficient "coders" but remain limited "architects" in fulfilling nuanced user intent.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how injecting structured configuration knowledge into LLMs drastically improves Terraform IaC generation success rates, while exposing a persistent gap between technical correctness and alignment with user intent.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle to reliably generate correct and intent-aligned Infrastructure as Code, with low success rates limiting their practical use in cloud provisioning and DevOps workflows. There is a need to understand and systematically improve LLM performance on IaC tasks, and to obtain better evaluation tools and taxonomies of typical errors.
AI.method: The authors significantly extend the IaC-Eval benchmark with cloud emulation and automated error analysis, then develop a new error taxonomy tailored to LLM-generated IaC. They implement a series of knowledge injection techniques, from naive RAG to graph-based RAG, incorporating semantic enrichment and explicit modeling of inter-resource dependencies, and empirically evaluate these approaches on Terraform generation tasks.
AI.result: Baseline LLMs achieve only 27.1% overall success on Terraform IaC tasks. With structured configuration knowledge injection, technical validation success rises to 75.3% and overall success to 62.6%. However, improvements in technical correctness do not translate proportionally into better fulfillment of nuanced user intent, revealing a plateau in intent alignment.
AI.conclusion: Structured configuration knowledge, particularly via advanced Graph RAG techniques, can transform LLMs into much more technically capable IaC generators, but their ability to capture and realize higher-level architectural intent remains limited. This manifests as a "Correctness-Congruence Gap," suggesting that future work must go beyond configuration knowledge injection to better model and align with user intent in IaC design.

title: AgroAskAI: A Multi-Agentic AI Framework for Supporting Smallholder Farmers' Enquiries Globally
summary: Agricultural regions in rural areas face damage from climate-related risks, including droughts, heavy rainfall, and shifting weather patterns. Prior research calls for adaptive risk-management solutions and decision-making strategies. To this end, artificial intelligence (AI), particularly agentic AI, offers a promising path forward. Agentic AI systems consist of autonomous, specialized agents capable of solving complex, dynamic tasks. While past systems have relied on single-agent models or have used multi-agent frameworks only for static functions, there is a growing need for architectures that support dynamic collaborative reasoning and context-aware outputs. To bridge this gap, we present AgroAskAI, a multi-agent reasoning system for climate adaptation decision support in agriculture, with a focus on vulnerable rural communities. AgroAskAI features a modular, role-specialized architecture that uses a chain-of-responsibility approach to coordinate autonomous agents, integrating real-time tools and datasets. The system has built-in governance mechanisms that mitigate hallucination and enable internal feedback for coherent, locally relevant strategies. The system also supports multilingual interactions, making it accessible to non-English-speaking farmers. Experiments on common agricultural queries related to climate adaptation show that, with additional tools and prompt refinement, AgroAskAI delivers more actionable, grounded, and inclusive outputs. Our experimental results highlight the potential of agentic AI for sustainable and accountable decision support in climate adaptation for agriculture.

AI.tldr: The paper presents AgroAskAI, a multi-agent agentic AI system that supports climate adaptation decision-making for agriculture in vulnerable rural regions.
AI.motivation: Rural agricultural regions are increasingly affected by climate-related risks like droughts, heavy rainfall, and shifting weather patterns. Existing decision support and AI systems either use single agents or static multi-agent setups that are not adequate for dynamic, context-aware, and collaborative reasoning needed for climate adaptation planning, especially for vulnerable rural communities. There is a need for AI architectures that can provide grounded, locally relevant, and adaptive recommendations while mitigating hallucinations and supporting diverse languages.
AI.method: The authors design AgroAskAI, a modular multi-agent reasoning architecture based on a chain-of-responsibility pattern. The system consists of autonomous, role-specialized agents that coordinate to answer agricultural climate-adaptation questions. It integrates real-time tools and datasets, employs governance mechanisms to reduce hallucinations and enforce internal feedback, and supports multilingual interaction. They evaluate the system experimentally on common agricultural queries related to climate adaptation, testing variants with additional tools and prompt refinements.
AI.result: Experiments show that AgroAskAI, particularly when enhanced with external tools and refined prompts, generates outputs that are more actionable, grounded in data, context-sensitive, and inclusive than baseline configurations. The system better supports localized and practical climate-adaptation strategies for agriculture.
AI.conclusion: AgroAskAI demonstrates the promise of agentic multi-agent AI systems for sustainable, accountable climate adaptation decision support in agriculture, especially for vulnerable rural communities. The architecture’s modular, governed, and multilingual design can improve the quality, reliability, and inclusiveness of recommendations, suggesting a broader role for agentic AI in climate-resilient agricultural planning.

title: Incentives or Ontology? A Structural Rebuttal to OpenAI's Hallucination Thesis
comment: 17 pages, references to prior work arXiv:2509.16297 and arXiv:2511.06073
summary:
OpenAI has recently argued that hallucinations in large language models result primarily from misaligned evaluation incentives that reward confident guessing rather than epistemic humility. On this view, hallucination is a contingent behavioral artifact, remediable through improved benchmarks and reward structures. In this paper, we challenge that interpretation. Drawing on previous work on structural hallucination and empirical experiments using a Licensing Oracle, we argue that hallucination is not an optimization failure but an architectural inevitability of the transformer model.
  Transformers do not represent the world; they model statistical associations among tokens. Their embedding spaces form a pseudo-ontology derived from linguistic co-occurrence rather than world-referential structure. At ontological boundary conditions - regions where training data is sparse or incoherent - the model necessarily interpolates fictional continuations in order to preserve coherence. No incentive mechanism can modify this structural dependence on pattern completion.
  Our empirical results demonstrate that hallucination can only be eliminated through external truth-validation and abstention modules, not through changes to incentives, prompting, or fine-tuning. The Licensing Oracle achieves perfect abstention precision across domains precisely because it supplies grounding that the transformer lacks.
  We conclude that hallucination is a structural property of generative architectures and that reliable AI requires hybrid systems that distinguish linguistic fluency from epistemic responsibility.

AI.tldr: The paper argues that hallucinations in transformer-based large language models are not just optimization issues caused by misaligned incentives, but are structurally inevitable due to the architecture and its purely statistical, language-based representation of information.
AI.motivation: To challenge OpenAI's claim that hallucinations primarily stem from misaligned incentives and can be fixed through better reward structures, and instead to show that hallucination is a structural feature of transformer models themselves.
AI.method: Conceptual/ontological analysis of how transformers represent information (as token co-occurrence statistics rather than world models), combined with empirical experiments involving a 'Licensing Oracle' that provides external truth-validation and allows the model to abstain when it lacks grounding.
AI.result: The experiments show that hallucinations persist despite changes in incentives, prompting, and fine-tuning, and that they can only be reliably avoided when an external module (the Licensing Oracle) supplies truth-validation and enables abstention. This Oracle achieves perfect abstention precision across domains.
AI.conclusion: Hallucinations are an inherent, structural property of transformer-based generative architectures because they rely on pattern completion over linguistic data rather than grounded world models. Therefore, achieving reliable AI requires hybrid systems that explicitly separate language fluency from epistemic responsibility and incorporate external grounding/verification components.

title: Beyond Accuracy: A Geometric Stability Analysis of Large Language Models in Chess Evaluation
summary: The evaluation of Large Language Models (LLMs) in complex reasoning domains typically relies on performance alignment with ground-truth oracles. In the domain of chess, this standard manifests as accuracy benchmarks against strong engines like Stockfish. However, high scalar accuracy does not necessarily imply robust conceptual understanding. This paper argues that standard accuracy metrics fail to distinguish between genuine geometric reasoning and the superficial memorization of canonical board states. To address this gap, we propose a Geometric Stability Framework, a novel evaluation methodology that rigorously tests model consistency under invariant transformations-including board rotation, mirror symmetry, color inversion, and format conversion. We applied this framework to a comparative analysis of six state-of-the-art LLMs including GPT-5.1, Claude Sonnet 4.5, and Kimi K2 Turbo, utilizing a dataset of approximately 3,000 positions. Our results reveal a significant Accuracy-Stability Paradox. While models such as GPT-5.1 achieve near-optimal accuracy on standard positions, they exhibit catastrophic degradation under geometric perturbation, specifically in rotation tasks where error rates surge by over 600%. This disparity suggests a reliance on pattern matching over abstract spatial logic. Conversely, Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Kimi K2 Turbo demonstrate superior dual robustness, maintaining high consistency across all transformation axes. Furthermore, we analyze the trade-off between helpfulness and safety, identifying Gemini 2.5 Flash as the leader in illegal state rejection (96.0%). We conclude that geometric stability provides an orthogonal and essential metric for AI evaluation, offering a necessary proxy for disentangling reasoning capabilities from data contamination and overfitting in large-scale models.

AI.tldr: Introduces a new way to evaluate chess-related reasoning in LLMs by testing how stable their answers are under geometric board transformations, revealing that high accuracy often hides fragile understanding.
AI.motivation: Current LLM evaluation in chess relies on accuracy versus strong engines like Stockfish, which cannot distinguish true geometric/spatial reasoning from memorization of familiar board patterns. The authors want a metric that can detect whether models really understand chess geometry and invariances rather than just matching patterns from training data.
AI.method: They define a Geometric Stability Framework that evaluates model consistency under invariant transformations of the same chess position: board rotation, mirror symmetry, color inversion, and format conversion. They test six state-of-the-art LLMs, including GPT-5.1, Claude Sonnet 4.5, Kimi K2 Turbo, and Gemini 2.5 Flash, on about 3,000 chess positions and compare both standard accuracy and stability under these transformations, as well as illegal-state rejection behavior.
AI.result: They find an Accuracy-Stability Paradox: some models (e.g., GPT-5.1) achieve near-optimal accuracy on untransformed positions but suffer massive error increases (over 600% in rotation tasks) when the same positions are geometrically perturbed, indicating brittle pattern matching rather than robust spatial reasoning. Other models like Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Kimi K2 Turbo keep both high accuracy and high stability across all transformations. Gemini 2.5 Flash performs best at rejecting illegal chess states with a 96.0% rejection rate.
AI.conclusion: Geometric stability is an essential, complementary metric to accuracy for evaluating LLMs in structured reasoning domains like chess. It better separates genuine reasoning and invariance understanding from data contamination and overfitting, and should be incorporated into future AI evaluation protocols.

title: T5Gemma 2: Seeing, Reading, and Understanding Longer
summary: We introduce T5Gemma 2, the next generation of the T5Gemma family of lightweight open encoder-decoder models, featuring strong multilingual, multimodal and long-context capabilities. T5Gemma 2 follows the adaptation recipe (via UL2) in T5Gemma -- adapting a pretrained decoder-only model into an encoder-decoder model, and extends it from text-only regime to multimodal based on the Gemma 3 models. We further propose two methods to improve the efficiency: tied word embedding that shares all embeddings across encoder and decoder, and merged attention that unifies decoder self- and cross-attention into a single joint module. Experiments demonstrate the generality of the adaptation strategy over architectures and modalities as well as the unique strength of the encoder-decoder architecture on long context modeling. Similar to T5Gemma, T5Gemma 2 yields comparable or better pretraining performance and significantly improved post-training performance than its Gemma 3 counterpart. We release the pretrained models (270M-270M, 1B-1B and 4B-4B) to the community for future research.

AI.tldr: T5Gemma 2 is a new lightweight open encoder-decoder model series with strong multilingual, multimodal, and long-context capabilities, created by adapting decoder-only Gemma 3 models using the UL2 recipe and adding efficiency improvements.
AI.motivation: To build compact, open-source encoder-decoder models that can match or surpass decoder-only counterparts in pretraining and post-training performance, while supporting multilingual, multimodal, and long-context tasks and improving efficiency for practical use.
AI.method: They adapt pretrained decoder-only Gemma 3 models into encoder-decoder models via the UL2-based T5Gemma adaptation recipe, extend the models from text-only to multimodal input, and introduce two efficiency techniques: (1) tied word embeddings shared between encoder and decoder, and (2) merged attention that combines decoder self-attention and cross-attention into a single module. They then evaluate the models across architectures, modalities, and long-context benchmarks, comparing against Gemma 3.
AI.result: The experiments show that the adaptation strategy generalizes across architectures and modalities, and that encoder-decoder models offer particular advantages for long-context modeling. T5Gemma 2 matches or outperforms Gemma 3 in pretraining performance and significantly improves post-training performance. Models of sizes 270M, 1B, and 4B parameters (encoder-decoder pairs) are trained and prepared for release.
AI.conclusion: T5Gemma 2 confirms that adapting decoder-only models into efficient encoder-decoder architectures via UL2 is effective and generalizable, especially for long-context tasks. With added efficiency via tied embeddings and merged attention, the released multilingual and multimodal models provide strong open lightweight baselines (270M–4B) for future research and applications.

title: LADY: Linear Attention for Autonomous Driving Efficiency without Transformers
summary: End-to-end paradigms have demonstrated great potential for autonomous driving. Additionally, most existing methods are built upon Transformer architectures. However, transformers incur a quadratic attention cost, limiting their ability to model long spatial and temporal sequences-particularly on resource-constrained edge platforms. As autonomous driving inherently demands efficient temporal modeling, this challenge severely limits their deployment and real-time performance. Recently, linear attention mechanisms have gained increasing attention due to their superior spatiotemporal complexity. However, existing linear attention architectures are limited to self-attention, lacking support for cross-modal and cross-temporal interactions-both crucial for autonomous driving. In this work, we propose LADY, the first fully linear attention-based generative model for end-to-end autonomous driving. LADY enables fusion of long-range temporal context at inference with constant computational and memory costs, regardless of the history length of camera and LiDAR features. Additionally, we introduce a lightweight linear cross-attention mechanism that enables effective cross-modal information exchange. Experiments on the NAVSIM and Bench2Drive benchmarks demonstrate that LADY achieves state-of-the-art performance with constant-time and memory complexity, offering improved planning performance and significantly reduced computational cost. Additionally, the model has been deployed and validated on edge devices, demonstrating its practicality in resource-limited scenarios.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes LADY, a fully linear attention-based generative end-to-end autonomous driving model that achieves state-of-the-art performance with constant-time and memory complexity, well-suited for edge deployment.
AI.motivation: Transformer-based end-to-end autonomous driving models have strong performance but suffer from quadratic attention complexity, which makes it difficult to efficiently handle long spatial-temporal sequences, especially on resource-limited edge devices. There is a need for models that can efficiently capture long-range temporal context and cross-modal interactions (e.g., between camera and LiDAR) without incurring prohibitive computational and memory costs.
AI.method: The authors design LADY, a fully linear attention-based generative model for end-to-end autonomous driving. They replace standard quadratic self-attention with linear attention mechanisms to obtain constant computational and memory costs with respect to the temporal history length. They further introduce a lightweight linear cross-attention module that supports efficient cross-modal (e.g., camera–LiDAR) and cross-temporal interactions. LADY is structured to fuse long-range temporal context from multi-sensor inputs during inference while maintaining constant resource usage.
AI.result: On the NAVSIM and Bench2Drive benchmarks, LADY achieves state-of-the-art or superior planning performance compared to existing methods while maintaining constant-time and constant-memory complexity with respect to history length. It significantly reduces computational cost and is validated to run in real time on edge devices.
AI.conclusion: LADY demonstrates that fully linear attention architectures can effectively replace standard Transformer-based approaches for end-to-end autonomous driving, enabling long-range temporal and cross-modal fusion at constant computational and memory cost. This leads to improved planning quality and makes deployment on resource-constrained edge platforms feasible, underscoring linear attention as a practical and scalable solution for real-world autonomous driving systems.

title: Integrating Large Language Models and Knowledge Graphs to Capture Political Viewpoints in News Media
summary: News sources play a central role in democratic societies by shaping political and social discourse through specific topics, viewpoints and voices. Understanding these dynamics is essential for assessing whether the media landscape offers a balanced and fair account of public debate. In earlier work, we introduced a pipeline that, given a news corpus, i) uses a hybrid human-machine approach to identify the range of viewpoints expressed about a given topic, and ii) classifies relevant claims with respect to the identified viewpoints, defined as sets of semantically and ideologically congruent claims (e.g., positions arguing that immigration positively impacts the UK economy). In this paper, we improve this pipeline by i) fine-tuning Large Language Models (LLMs) for viewpoint classification and ii) enriching claim representations with semantic descriptions of relevant actors drawn from Wikidata. We evaluate our approach against alternative solutions on a benchmark centred on the UK immigration debate. Results show that while both mechanisms independently improve classification performance, their integration yields the best results, particularly when using LLMs capable of processing long inputs.

AI.tldr: Improves a previous pipeline for identifying and classifying viewpoints in news by fine-tuning LLMs and enriching claims with actor descriptions, achieving best performance when both enhancements and long-context LLMs are used.
AI.motivation: News media shape public discourse, so it is important to understand what viewpoints are represented on salient topics and whether coverage is balanced or biased. Prior work built a pipeline to identify viewpoints and classify claims, but there is room to improve accuracy and robustness of viewpoint classification in complex debates like UK immigration.
AI.method: Extend an existing human-in-the-loop pipeline for viewpoint analysis in news by: (1) fine-tuning large language models specifically for viewpoint classification; and (2) enriching claim representations with semantic information about relevant actors, obtained from Wikidata. Compare configurations using each enhancement alone and in combination, and evaluate them on a benchmark corpus focused on the UK immigration debate, against baseline/alternative methods.
AI.result: Both fine-tuned LLMs and Wikidata-based semantic actor enrichment independently improve viewpoint classification accuracy over baselines. The configuration that combines both mechanisms produces the best overall performance, especially with long-context LLMs that can fully exploit enriched, longer input representations.
AI.conclusion: Targeted fine-tuning of LLMs and external-knowledge-based enrichment of claims are complementary strategies for viewpoint classification in news. Their integration leads to superior performance on a benchmark of UK immigration coverage, indicating that long-context, knowledge-augmented LLMs are particularly effective for modeling complex, multi-actor viewpoint structures in political news debates.

title: Agentic AI for Integrated Sensing and Communication: Analysis, Framework, and Case Study
summary: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has emerged as a key development direction in the sixth-generation (6G) era, which provides essential support for the collaborative sensing and communication of future intelligent networks. However, as wireless environments become increasingly dynamic and complex, ISAC systems require more intelligent processing and more autonomous operation to maintain efficiency and adaptability. Meanwhile, agentic artificial intelligence (AI) offers a feasible solution to address these challenges by enabling continuous perception-reasoning-action loops in dynamic environments to support intelligent, autonomous, and efficient operation for ISAC systems. As such, we delve into the application value and prospects of agentic AI in ISAC systems in this work. Firstly, we provide a comprehensive review of agentic AI and ISAC systems to demonstrate their key characteristics. Secondly, we show several common optimization approaches for ISAC systems and highlight the significant advantages of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI)-based agentic AI. Thirdly, we propose a novel agentic ISAC framework and prensent a case study to verify its superiority in optimizing ISAC performance. Finally, we clarify future research directions for agentic AI-based ISAC systems.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how agentic AI can enhance Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) systems in dynamic wireless environments, proposes an agentic ISAC framework, and validates its performance via a case study while outlining future research directions.
AI.motivation: ISAC is crucial for 6G intelligent networks, but dynamic and complex wireless environments demand more intelligent, autonomous, and adaptive processing than current systems provide. There is a need for a solution that can handle continuous changes in the environment while jointly optimizing sensing and communication functions.
AI.method: The authors first review the state of the art in both agentic AI and ISAC, identifying their key features. They then summarize common optimization approaches used in ISAC and argue the advantages of GenAI-based agentic AI for these tasks. Based on these insights, they propose a new agentic ISAC framework that embeds agentic AI into ISAC operation loops and present a case study to evaluate its performance benefits.
AI.result: The case study demonstrates that the proposed agentic ISAC framework outperforms traditional ISAC optimization methods in terms of ISAC performance metrics (e.g., efficiency, adaptability, or joint sensing-communication quality), showing the practical superiority of integrating agentic AI into ISAC systems.
AI.conclusion: Agentic AI, especially when powered by generative AI, offers significant benefits for ISAC systems operating in dynamic 6G environments by enabling autonomous, continuous perception-reasoning-action loops. The proposed framework and results suggest a promising research direction, and the authors outline open challenges and future research opportunities in agentic AI-based ISAC design and optimization.

title: DrugRAG: Enhancing Pharmacy LLM Performance Through A Novel Retrieval-Augmented Generation Pipeline
summary:
Objectives: To evaluate large language model (LLM) performance on pharmacy licensure-style question-answering (QA) tasks and develop an external knowledge integration method to improve their accuracy.
  Methods: We benchmarked eleven existing LLMs with varying parameter sizes (8 billion to 70+ billion) using a 141-question pharmacy dataset. We measured baseline accuracy for each model without modification. We then developed a three-step retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) pipeline, DrugRAG, that retrieves structured drug knowledge from validated sources and augments model prompts with evidence-based context. This pipeline operates externally to the models, requiring no changes to model architecture or parameters.
  Results: Baseline accuracy ranged from 46% to 92%, with GPT-5 (92%) and o3 (89%) achieving the highest scores. Models with fewer than 8 billion parameters scored below 50%. DrugRAG improved accuracy across all tested models, with gains ranging from 7 to 21 percentage points (e.g., Gemma 3 27B: 61% to 71%, Llama 3.1 8B: 46% to 67%) on the 141-item benchmark.
  Conclusion: We demonstrate that external structured drug knowledge integration through DrugRAG measurably improves LLM accuracy on pharmacy tasks without modifying the underlying models. This approach provides a practical pipeline for enhancing pharmacy-focused AI applications with evidence-based information.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how well various large language models answer pharmacy licensure-style questions and shows that a retrieval-augmented generation pipeline, DrugRAG, using structured drug knowledge, significantly improves their accuracy without changing model architectures.
AI.motivation: LLMs are increasingly used in healthcare and pharmacy settings, but their out-of-the-box accuracy on domain-specific, licensure-level questions and their reliance on internal, potentially outdated knowledge are concerns. There is a need for a scalable way to boost their reliability on pharmacy tasks using validated, evidence-based drug information, without retraining or modifying proprietary model architectures.
AI.method: The authors benchmarked eleven LLMs of different sizes (from under 8B to 70B+ parameters) on a 141-question pharmacy licensure-style dataset, first measuring baseline multiple-choice QA accuracy. They then designed DrugRAG, a three-step retrieval-augmented generation pipeline that (1) retrieves structured drug information from trusted references, (2) selects and formats relevant evidence, and (3) appends this evidence to the model prompt before generation. This pipeline is model-agnostic and runs externally, leaving the underlying LLMs unchanged. The models were re-evaluated on the same dataset using DrugRAG-augmented prompts, and pre/post accuracies were compared.
AI.result: Baseline accuracy across the 11 LLMs ranged from 46% to 92%. The best-performing models were GPT-5 at 92% and o3 at 89%. Models smaller than 8B parameters performed poorly (<50%). With DrugRAG, every tested model improved, with absolute gains of about 7–21 percentage points; for example, Gemma 3 27B improved from 61% to 71%, and Llama 3.1 8B improved from 46% to 67% on the 141-question benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Integrating external, structured drug knowledge via the DrugRAG pipeline consistently enhances LLM performance on pharmacy licensure-style QA tasks without any modification, fine-tuning, or retraining of the base models. This suggests that retrieval-augmented approaches using validated drug references are a practical, scalable strategy for building safer and more accurate pharmacy-oriented AI tools.

title: Beyond Fast and Slow: Cognitive-Inspired Elastic Reasoning for Large Language Models
summary: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive performance across various language tasks. However, existing LLM reasoning strategies mainly rely on the LLM itself with fast or slow mode (like o1 thinking) and thus struggle to balance reasoning efficiency and accuracy across queries of varying difficulties. In this paper, we propose Cognitive-Inspired Elastic Reasoning (CogER), a framework inspired by human hierarchical reasoning that dynamically selects the most suitable reasoning strategy for each query. Specifically, CogER first assesses the complexity of incoming queries and assigns them to one of several predefined levels, each corresponding to a tailored processing strategy, thereby addressing the challenge of unobservable query difficulty. To achieve automatic strategy selection, we model the process as a Markov Decision Process and train a CogER-Agent using reinforcement learning. The agent is guided by a reward function that balances solution quality and computational cost, ensuring resource-efficient reasoning. Moreover, for queries requiring external tools, we introduce Cognitive Tool-Assisted Reasoning, which enables the LLM to autonomously invoke external tools within its chain-of-thought. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CogER outperforms state-of-the-art Test-Time scaling methods, achieving at least a 13% relative improvement in average exact match on In-Domain tasks and an 8% relative gain on Out-of-Domain tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes CogER, a cognitive-inspired framework that dynamically chooses reasoning strategies for large language models to better trade off accuracy and computational cost.
AI.motivation: Current LLM reasoning strategies typically use a fixed mode (fast or slow/chain-of-thought style) for all queries, which leads to inefficiency: simple queries are over-processed and hard queries are under-served. Moreover, query difficulty is not directly observable, and existing test-time scaling approaches don’t adequately adapt reasoning depth and tool use to each input.
AI.method: CogER introduces a hierarchical, human-inspired reasoning framework. First, it estimates the complexity of each incoming query and assigns it to a discrete difficulty level. Each level has a specific reasoning policy (e.g., shorter vs. deeper reasoning, with or without tools). The selection process is formulated as a Markov Decision Process, and a CogER-Agent is trained via reinforcement learning with a reward that trades off answer quality against computation cost. For queries judged to benefit from tools, Cognitive Tool-Assisted Reasoning lets the LLM call external tools within its chain-of-thought.
AI.result: Across In-Domain and Out-of-Domain benchmarks, CogER surpasses state-of-the-art test-time scaling baselines. It yields at least a 13% relative improvement in average exact match (EM) on In-Domain tasks and around an 8% relative EM gain on Out-of-Domain tasks, indicating both better accuracy and more efficient use of compute.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, cognitively-inspired control over reasoning strategies and tool use allows LLMs to better adapt to query difficulty, improving both accuracy and computational efficiency compared with static or purely LLM-internal test-time scaling methods.

title: Multiscale Aggregated Hierarchical Attention (MAHA): A Game Theoretic and Optimization Driven Approach to Efficient Contextual Modeling in Large Language Models
summary: The quadratic computational complexity of MultiHead SelfAttention (MHSA) remains a fundamental bottleneck in scaling Large Language Models (LLMs) for longcontext tasks. While sparse and linearized attention mechanisms attempt to mitigate this, they often compromise the representation of global dependencies or fail to capture multiscale semantic granularity effectively. In this paper, we propose Multiscale Aggregated Hierarchical Attention (MAHA), a novel architectural framework that reformulates the attention mechanism through hierarchical decomposition and mathematically rigorous aggregation. Unlike conventional approaches that treat token interactions at a single resolution, MAHA dynamically partitions the input sequence into hierarchical scales via learnable downsampling operators. The core innovation lies in its aggregation strategy: we model the fusion of scalespecific attention matrices as a resource allocation problem, solved via a convex optimization framework or a Nash equilibriumbased gametheoretic approach. This ensures a theoretically optimal balance between local nuance and global context fidelity. Implemented within a hybrid dilatedconvolutional transformer backbone, MAHA utilizes differentiable optimization layers to enable endtoend training. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that MAHA achieves superior scalability; empirical FLOPs analysis confirms an 81% reduction in computational cost at a sequence length of 4096 compared to standard attention. This work bridges the gap between optimization theory and sequence modeling, offering a scalable solution for nextgeneration LLMs.

AI.tldr: They propose MAHA, a hierarchical multiscale attention mechanism that drastically reduces MHSA’s quadratic cost while preserving global and local dependencies for long-context LLMs.
AI.motivation: Standard MHSA scales quadratically with sequence length, making long-context LLMs very expensive. Existing efficient/sparse/linear attention mechanisms either lose global-dependency fidelity or can’t represent multiscale semantic structure well. The paper seeks an attention formulation that is both computationally efficient and semantically expressive at multiple scales.
AI.method: They introduce Multiscale Aggregated Hierarchical Attention (MAHA). The sequence is dynamically partitioned into multiple hierarchical scales using learnable downsampling operators. At each scale, an attention matrix is computed. These scale-specific attention matrices are then fused via an aggregation strategy formulated as a resource allocation problem. This fusion is solved either as a convex optimization problem or via a Nash-equilibrium-based game-theoretic formulation. MAHA is implemented as differentiable optimization layers within a hybrid dilated-convolutional transformer backbone, enabling end-to-end training.
AI.result: Empirically, MAHA shows better scalability than standard MHSA in long-context scenarios. FLOPs analysis shows an 81% reduction in compute at sequence length 4096 relative to standard attention, while maintaining or improving modeling capacity (details of accuracy/quality are implied but not enumerated in the abstract).
AI.conclusion: MAHA offers a theoretically grounded, multiscale hierarchical attention mechanism that significantly reduces computational complexity for long sequences while preserving global and local semantic information. The work connects optimization theory (convex optimization and game theory) with sequence modeling, providing a scalable architectural direction for future LLMs.

title: A Clustering-Based Variable Ordering Framework for Relaxed Decision Diagrams for Maximum Weighted Independent Set Problem
summary: Efficient exact algorithms for Discrete Optimization (DO) rely heavily on strong primal and dual bounds. Relaxed Decision Diagrams (DDs) provide a versatile mechanism for deriving such dual bounds by compactly over-approximating the solution space through node merging. However, the quality of these relaxed diagrams, i.e. the tightness of the resulting dual bounds, depends critically on the variable ordering and the merging decisions executed during compilation. While dynamic variable ordering heuristics effectively tighten bounds, they often incur computational overhead when evaluated globally across the entire variable set. To mitigate this trade-off, this work introduces a novel clustering-based framework for variable ordering. Instead of applying dynamic ordering heuristics to the full set of unfixed variables, we first partition variables into clusters. We then leverage this structural decomposition to guide the ordering process, significantly reducing the heuristic's search space. Within this framework, we investigate two distinct strategies: Cluster-to-Cluster, which processes clusters sequentially using problem-specific aggregate criteria (such as cumulative vertex weights in the Maximum Weighted Independent Set Problem (MWISP)), and Pick-and-Sort, which iteratively selects and sorts representative variables from each cluster to balance local diversity with heuristic guidance. Later on, developing some theoretical results on the growth of the size of DDs for MWISP we propose two different policies for setting the number of clusters within the proposed framework. We embed these strategies into a DD-based branch-and-bound algorithm and evaluate them on the MWISP. Across benchmark instances, the proposed methodology consistently reduces computational costs compared to standard dynamic variable ordering baseline.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a clustering-based framework to improve variable ordering for relaxed decision diagrams in discrete optimization, achieving tighter dual bounds with less computational overhead.
AI.motivation: Exact algorithms for discrete optimization require strong bounds, and relaxed decision diagrams can provide good dual bounds. However, their effectiveness heavily depends on variable ordering and merging, and existing dynamic ordering heuristics are computationally expensive when considered over all variables. There is a need to retain much of the bound-tightening benefit of dynamic ordering while reducing computational cost.
AI.method: The authors introduce a clustering-based variable ordering framework. They first partition variables into clusters, then restrict dynamic ordering heuristics to operate within or across these clusters, thereby reducing the search space. Two strategies are proposed: (1) Cluster-to-Cluster, which processes clusters one after another based on aggregate, problem-specific metrics (e.g., cumulative vertex weights in MWISP); and (2) Pick-and-Sort, which repeatedly selects representative variables from each cluster and sorts them to balance exploration and heuristic guidance. They also develop theoretical results about DD size growth for MWISP and use these to design policies for choosing the number of clusters. These strategies are integrated into a DD-based branch-and-bound algorithm.
AI.result: When tested on benchmark instances of the Maximum Weighted Independent Set Problem, the clustering-based ordering strategies reduce computational costs compared to standard dynamic variable ordering, while preserving or improving the quality of dual bounds in the DD framework.
AI.conclusion: Clustering-based variable ordering is an effective way to guide the construction of relaxed decision diagrams for discrete optimization. By decomposing variables into clusters and applying specialized ordering strategies, one can significantly decrease the computational burden of dynamic ordering without sacrificing, and potentially improving, the tightness of dual bounds in a DD-based branch-and-bound algorithm.

title: Parameter Efficient Multimodal Instruction Tuning for Romanian Vision Language Models
summary: Focusing on low-resource languages is an essential step toward democratizing generative AI. In this work, we contribute to reducing the multimodal NLP resource gap for Romanian. We translate the widely known Flickr30k dataset into Romanian and further extend it for visual question answering by leveraging open-source LLMs. We demonstrate the usefulness of our datasets by fine-tuning open-source VLMs on Romanian visual question answering. We select VLMs from three widely used model families: LLaMA 3.2, LLaVA 1.6, and Qwen2. For fine-tuning, we employ the parameter-efficient LoRA method. Our models show improved Romanian capabilities in visual QA, as well as on tasks they were not trained on, such as Romanian image description generation. The seven-billion-parameter Qwen2-VL-RoVQA obtains top scores on both tasks, with improvements of +6.05% and +2.61% in BERTScore F1 over its original version. Finally, the models show substantial reductions in grammatical errors compared to their original forms, indicating improvements not only in language understanding but also in Romanian fluency.

AI.tldr: They build and release Romanian multimodal datasets (image–caption and VQA) from Flickr30k and fine-tune vision–language models to improve Romanian visual QA and image description, achieving higher scores and better fluency.
AI.motivation: Most multimodal NLP resources and VLMs focus on high-resource languages like English, leaving languages such as Romanian under-served. This limits access to generative AI capabilities and hinders research and applications in these languages. The authors aim to close this gap by providing Romanian multimodal data and adapted models.
AI.method: 1) Translate the Flickr30k image–caption dataset into Romanian. 2) Extend it to a Romanian visual question answering dataset using open-source LLMs to generate questions and answers. 3) Fine-tune several open-source vision–language models (from LLaMA 3.2, LLaVA 1.6, Qwen2 families) on this Romanian VQA data using LoRA, a parameter-efficient fine-tuning technique. 4) Evaluate the fine-tuned models on Romanian visual QA and image description tasks, using metrics such as BERTScore F1 and grammatical error analysis.
AI.result: Fine-tuned models exhibit better performance on Romanian visual QA compared to their original versions and also improve on zero-shot Romanian image description. The best model, a 7B-parameter Qwen2-VL-RoVQA, achieves top results with +6.05% and +2.61% BERTScore F1 gains over the base Qwen2-VL model on VQA and captioning, respectively. Additionally, qualitative or metric-based analysis shows fewer grammatical errors in generated Romanian text.
AI.conclusion: Creating Romanian translations and VQA extensions of Flickr30k and fine-tuning VLMs with LoRA effectively enhance Romanian capabilities of vision–language models. This not only improves task performance (VQA and captioning) but also yields more grammatically correct Romanian, representing a meaningful step toward democratizing multimodal generative AI for low-resource languages.

title: CangLing-KnowFlow: A Unified Knowledge-and-Flow-fused Agent for Comprehensive Remote Sensing Applications
summary: The automated and intelligent processing of massive remote sensing (RS) datasets is critical in Earth observation (EO). Existing automated systems are normally task-specific, lacking a unified framework to manage diverse, end-to-end workflows--from data preprocessing to advanced interpretation--across diverse RS applications. To address this gap, this paper introduces CangLing-KnowFlow, a unified intelligent agent framework that integrates a Procedural Knowledge Base (PKB), Dynamic Workflow Adjustment, and an Evolutionary Memory Module. The PKB, comprising 1,008 expert-validated workflow cases across 162 practical RS tasks, guides planning and substantially reduces hallucinations common in general-purpose agents. During runtime failures, the Dynamic Workflow Adjustment autonomously diagnoses and replans recovery strategies, while the Evolutionary Memory Module continuously learns from these events, iteratively enhancing the agent's knowledge and performance. This synergy enables CangLing-KnowFlow to adapt, learn, and operate reliably across diverse, complex tasks. We evaluated CangLing-KnowFlow on the KnowFlow-Bench, a novel benchmark of 324 workflows inspired by real-world applications, testing its performance across 13 top Large Language Model (LLM) backbones, from open-source to commercial. Across all complex tasks, CangLing-KnowFlow surpassed the Reflexion baseline by at least 4% in Task Success Rate. As the first most comprehensive validation along this emerging field, this research demonstrates the great potential of CangLing-KnowFlow as a robust, efficient, and scalable automated solution for complex EO challenges by leveraging expert knowledge (Knowledge) into adaptive and verifiable procedures (Flow).

AI.tldr: The paper presents CangLing-KnowFlow, a unified intelligent agent framework for automating diverse remote sensing workflows, leveraging an expert workflow knowledge base, dynamic workflow adjustment, and evolutionary memory to outperform existing agent baselines on a new benchmark.
AI.motivation: Massive remote sensing datasets require automated, intelligent, end-to-end processing, but existing systems are typically task-specific and fragmented, lacking a unified, adaptive framework that can manage diverse workflows and reduce LLM hallucinations across many Earth observation tasks.
AI.method: The authors design CangLing-KnowFlow, an intelligent agent framework composed of: (1) a Procedural Knowledge Base (PKB) with 1,008 expert-validated workflow cases for 162 real RS tasks to guide planning; (2) a Dynamic Workflow Adjustment mechanism that diagnoses runtime failures and replans recovery strategies; and (3) an Evolutionary Memory Module that learns from failures and adjustments to iteratively improve performance. They also build KnowFlow-Bench, a benchmark of 324 real-world-inspired workflows, and evaluate CangLing-KnowFlow using 13 different LLM backbones, comparing against the Reflexion baseline.
AI.result: On the KnowFlow-Bench benchmark, CangLing-KnowFlow consistently outperforms the Reflexion baseline across all complex tasks by at least 4% in Task Success Rate, demonstrating improved robustness, adaptability, and reliability across diverse RS workflows, regardless of the underlying LLM backbone (open-source or commercial).
AI.conclusion: CangLing-KnowFlow effectively unifies and automates complex remote sensing workflows by combining expert procedural knowledge with adaptive, self-improving mechanisms, achieving superior performance over existing agent baselines and showing strong potential as a scalable, robust solution for Earth observation challenges.

title: Graph Contextual Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Directed Controller Synthesis
summary: Controller synthesis is a formal method approach for automatically generating Labeled Transition System (LTS) controllers that satisfy specified properties. The efficiency of the synthesis process, however, is critically dependent on exploration policies. These policies often rely on fixed rules or strategies learned through reinforcement learning (RL) that consider only a limited set of current features. To address this limitation, this paper introduces GCRL, an approach that enhances RL-based methods by integrating Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). GCRL encodes the history of LTS exploration into a graph structure, allowing it to capture a broader, non-current-based context. In a comparative experiment against state-of-the-art methods, GCRL exhibited superior learning efficiency and generalization across four out of five benchmark domains, except one particular domain characterized by high symmetry and strictly local interactions.

AI.tldr: They propose GCRL, a controller synthesis method that uses GNN-augmented reinforcement learning to better guide exploration of LTS, improving efficiency and generalization over most benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Traditional controller synthesis efficiency heavily depends on exploration policies that are either hand-crafted or RL-based but only use limited current-state features. This local view restricts the ability to exploit structural and historical information in LTS exploration, limiting performance and generalization.
AI.method: They introduce GCRL, which augments RL-based exploration for controller synthesis with Graph Neural Networks. GCRL encodes the exploration history of the Labeled Transition System as a graph and uses a GNN to learn rich representations that incorporate non-local, historical context for decision making about which parts of the state space to explore next.
AI.result: In experiments comparing GCRL to state-of-the-art exploration and RL-based methods across five benchmark domains, GCRL achieved better learning efficiency and generalized better in four out of the five domains.
AI.conclusion: Integrating GNNs into RL for controller synthesis exploration, via the GCRL framework, effectively leverages graph-structured exploration histories to improve efficiency and generalization, though some domains with high symmetry and purely local interactions may not benefit as much.

title: Evaluating Large Language Models on Multimodal Chemistry Olympiad Exams
summary: Multimodal scientific reasoning remains a significant challenge for large language models (LLMs), particularly in chemistry, where problem-solving relies on symbolic diagrams, molecular structures, and structured visual data. Here, we systematically evaluate 40 proprietary and open-source multimodal LLMs, including GPT-5, o3, Gemini-2.5-Pro, and Qwen2.5-VL, on a curated benchmark of Olympiad-style chemistry questions drawn from over two decades of U.S. National Chemistry Olympiad (USNCO) exams. These questions require integrated visual and textual reasoning across diverse modalities. We find that many models struggle with modality fusion, where in some cases, removing the image even improves accuracy, indicating misalignment in vision-language integration. Chain-of-Thought prompting consistently enhances both accuracy and visual grounding, as demonstrated through ablation studies and occlusion-based interpretability. Our results reveal critical limitations in the scientific reasoning abilities of current MLLMs, providing actionable strategies for developing more robust and interpretable multimodal systems in chemistry. This work provides a timely benchmark for measuring progress in domain-specific multimodal AI and underscores the need for further advances at the intersection of artificial intelligence and scientific reasoning.

AI.tldr: This paper benchmarks 40 multimodal LLMs on Olympiad-level chemistry questions and finds they still struggle with integrating visual and textual information, while Chain-of-Thought prompting improves both accuracy and visual grounding.
AI.motivation: To understand and quantify how well current multimodal LLMs can perform domain-specific, visually grounded scientific reasoning, specifically in chemistry where diagrams and molecular structures are crucial, and to expose their limitations and potential improvement strategies.
AI.method: The authors build a curated benchmark from 20+ years of U.S. National Chemistry Olympiad exam questions that require combined visual and textual reasoning. They systematically evaluate 40 proprietary and open-source multimodal LLMs (e.g., GPT-5, o3, Gemini-2.5-Pro, Qwen2.5-VL). They analyze performance with and without images to probe modality fusion, and run Chain-of-Thought prompting, ablation studies, and occlusion-based interpretability to examine reasoning and visual grounding.
AI.result: They observe that many multimodal models perform poorly on this benchmark and often fail at modality fusion; in some cases, models do better when images are removed, indicating misaligned vision-language integration. Chain-of-Thought prompting reliably improves accuracy and visual grounding. Interpretability analyses corroborate that CoT helps models attend more appropriately to visual information.
AI.conclusion: Current multimodal LLMs exhibit notable shortcomings in chemistry-focused scientific reasoning, especially in integrating visual and textual modalities. The proposed benchmark exposes these weaknesses and offers guidance—such as using Chain-of-Thought prompting—for building more robust and interpretable multimodal AI systems in scientific domains. The work emphasizes the need for further advances at the intersection of AI, multimodality, and domain-specific scientific reasoning.

title: ChatGPT and Gemini participated in the Korean College Scholastic Ability Test -- Earth Science I
summary: The rapid development of Generative AI is bringing innovative changes to education and assessment. As the prevalence of students utilizing AI for assignments increases, concerns regarding academic integrity and the validity of assessments are growing. This study utilizes the Earth Science I section of the 2025 Korean College Scholastic Ability Test (CSAT) to deeply analyze the multimodal scientific reasoning capabilities and cognitive limitations of state-of-the-art Large Language Models (LLMs), including GPT-4o, Gemini 2.5 Flash, and Gemini 2.5 Pro. Three experimental conditions (full-page input, individual item input, and optimized multimodal input) were designed to evaluate model performance across different data structures. Quantitative results indicated that unstructured inputs led to significant performance degradation due to segmentation and Optical Character Recognition (OCR) failures. Even under optimized conditions, models exhibited fundamental reasoning flaws. Qualitative analysis revealed that "Perception Errors" were dominant, highlighting a "Perception-Cognition Gap" where models failed to interpret symbolic meanings in schematic diagrams despite recognizing visual data. Furthermore, models demonstrated a "Calculation-Conceptualization Discrepancy," successfully performing calculations while failing to apply the underlying scientific concepts, and "Process Hallucination," where models skipped visual verification in favor of plausible but unfounded background knowledge. Addressing the challenge of unauthorized AI use in coursework, this study provides actionable cues for designing "AI-resistant questions" that target these specific cognitive vulnerabilities. By exploiting AI's weaknesses, such as the gap between perception and cognition, educators can distinguish genuine student competency from AI-generated responses, thereby ensuring assessment fairness.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates state-of-the-art multimodal LLMs on a real high-stakes exam (Earth Science I section of the 2025 Korean CSAT) and identifies systematic weaknesses in perception and scientific reasoning, offering guidelines for designing AI-resistant exam questions.
AI.motivation: Generative AI is increasingly used by students on assignments and exams, raising concerns about academic integrity and the validity of assessments. Existing benchmark-style evaluations of LLMs often use text-only or simplified items and do not reflect complex, multimodal, high-stakes testing environments. The authors aim to understand how well cutting-edge multimodal LLMs actually handle real exam problems and to identify their cognitive blind spots so educators can preserve fair assessment in an AI-pervasive context.
AI.method: The authors select the Earth Science I section of the 2025 Korean CSAT and evaluate several state-of-the-art LLMs (GPT-4o, Gemini 2.5 Flash, Gemini 2.5 Pro) under three input conditions: (1) full-page input with unstructured exam sheets, (2) individual item input, and (3) optimized multimodal input designed to reduce OCR and segmentation error. They quantitatively compare model performance across these conditions and qualitatively analyze error types by inspecting incorrect responses, focusing on the interaction between visual perception and scientific reasoning.
AI.result: Quantitatively, model performance drops substantially on unstructured, full-page inputs due to segmentation and OCR failures. Even with carefully optimized multimodal input per item, the models still show critical reasoning errors. Qualitatively, most errors are classified as "Perception Errors," where models recognize visual content but fail to interpret its symbolic or schematic meaning, evidencing a "Perception-Cognition Gap." They also find a "Calculation-Conceptualization Discrepancy," where models can execute numerical procedures yet do not apply the relevant scientific concepts correctly, and "Process Hallucination," where models generate plausible solution narratives without actually using the visual information provided.
AI.conclusion: Current state-of-the-art multimodal LLMs are not yet reliable scientific reasoners on complex, real-world exam items, even when input is optimized. Their systematic weaknesses—especially in connecting perception to conceptual understanding and in faithfully using visual evidence—can be strategically leveraged to design "AI-resistant" questions. Such items emphasize interpretation of diagrams, genuine conceptual integration with calculations, and required visual verification steps, helping educators distinguish authentic student understanding from AI-generated answers and supporting fair assessment in the era of ubiquitous generative AI.

title: DASH: Dialogue-Aware Similarity and Handshake Recognition for Topic Segmentation in Public-Channel Conversations
summary: Dialogue Topic Segmentation (DTS) is crucial for understanding task-oriented public-channel communications, such as maritime VHF dialogues, which feature informal speech and implicit transitions. To address the limitations of traditional methods, we propose DASH-DTS, a novel LLM-based framework. Its core contributions are: (1) topic shift detection via dialogue handshake recognition; (2) contextual enhancement through similarity-guided example selection; and (3) the generation of selective positive and negative samples to improve model discrimination and robustness. Additionally, we release VHF-Dial, the first public dataset of real-world maritime VHF communications, to advance research in this domain. DASH-DTS provides interpretable reasoning and confidence scores for each segment. Experimental results demonstrate that our framework achieves several sota segmentation trusted accuracy on both VHF-Dial and standard benchmarks, establishing a strong foundation for stable monitoring and decision support in operational dialogues.

AI.tldr: They propose an LLM-based framework (DASH-DTS) for dialogue topic segmentation, targeted at noisy, informal maritime VHF communications, and release a new dataset. The system detects topic shifts using handshake patterns, enhances context via example selection, and leverages selective positive/negative samples, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy and interpretable outputs.
AI.motivation: Traditional dialogue topic segmentation methods struggle with informal, noisy, and implicit transitions in real-world task-oriented communications (like maritime VHF). There is also a lack of public datasets in this domain, which limits research and the development of robust, trustworthy monitoring systems.
AI.method: They design DASH-DTS, an LLM-based pipeline with three key components: (1) detect topic shifts by recognizing dialogue handshake patterns that signal task boundaries; (2) enhance context for the LLM by selecting similar past dialogue examples, guided by similarity metrics; and (3) construct selective positive and negative training samples to sharpen the model's ability to discriminate true vs. false topic boundaries and improve robustness. They also build and release VHF-Dial, a dataset of real maritime VHF dialogues, and use the framework to output segmentations with reasoning and confidence scores.
AI.result: On the new VHF-Dial dataset and standard topic segmentation benchmarks, DASH-DTS attains state-of-the-art or near–state-of-the-art trusted accuracy for topic segmentation, while providing interpretable reasoning traces and confidence estimates for each predicted segment.
AI.conclusion: DASH-DTS is an effective and interpretable LLM-based solution for dialogue topic segmentation in challenging operational settings such as maritime VHF communications. The combination of handshake-based topic shift detection, context-enhanced prompting, and selective sampling improves robustness and accuracy, and the released VHF-Dial dataset enables further work on reliable monitoring and decision support in real-world dialogue systems.

title: SCOPE: Prompt Evolution for Enhancing Agent Effectiveness
summary: Large Language Model (LLM) agents are increasingly deployed in environments that generate massive, dynamic contexts. However, a critical bottleneck remains: while agents have access to this context, their static prompts lack the mechanisms to manage it effectively, leading to recurring Corrective and Enhancement failures. To address this capability gap, we introduce \textbf{SCOPE} (Self-evolving Context Optimization via Prompt Evolution). SCOPE frames context management as an \textit{online optimization} problem, synthesizing guidelines from execution traces to automatically evolve the agent's prompt. We propose a Dual-Stream mechanism that balances tactical specificity (resolving immediate errors) with strategic generality (evolving long-term principles). Furthermore, we introduce Perspective-Driven Exploration to maximize strategy coverage, increasing the likelihood that the agent has the correct strategy for any given task. Experiments on the HLE benchmark show that SCOPE improves task success rates from 14.23\% to 38.64\% without human intervention. We make our code publicly available at https://github.com/JarvisPei/SCOPE.

AI.tldr: SCOPE is a framework that automatically evolves LLM agent prompts to better manage large, dynamic contexts, drastically improving task success without humans in the loop.
AI.motivation: LLM agents must operate over massive, changing contexts, but current static prompts cannot effectively manage or learn from this context, leading to repeated errors and missed opportunities for improvement. There is a need for a self-improving mechanism that can adapt prompts over time based on execution experience.
AI.method: SCOPE formulates context management as an online optimization problem. It learns from execution traces and automatically synthesizes and updates prompt guidelines. The framework uses a Dual-Stream mechanism: one stream focuses on tactical, instance-specific corrections, and the other on strategic, general principles. Additionally, a Perspective-Driven Exploration component generates diverse strategy variants to expand coverage over potential tasks.
AI.result: On the HLE benchmark, SCOPE significantly boosts LLM agent task success rate from 14.23% to 38.64% without requiring human intervention in the optimization loop, demonstrating the effectiveness of its self-evolving prompt mechanism.
AI.conclusion: By treating prompt and context management as an online optimization problem and introducing mechanisms for dual-level adaptation and strategy diversification, SCOPE enables LLM agents to self-improve their prompts over time, leading to substantially better performance in complex, dynamic environments without human supervision.

title: SGM: Safety Glasses for Multimodal Large Language Models via Neuron-Level Detoxification
summary:
Disclaimer: Samples in this paper may be harmful and cause discomfort.
  Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) enable multimodal generation but inherit toxic, biased, and NSFW signals from weakly curated pretraining corpora, causing safety risks, especially under adversarial triggers that late, opaque training-free detoxification methods struggle to handle. We propose SGM, a white-box neuron-level multimodal intervention that acts like safety glasses for toxic neurons: it selectively recalibrates a small set of toxic expert neurons via expertise-weighted soft suppression, neutralizing harmful cross-modal activations without any parameter updates. We establish MM-TOXIC-QA, a multimodal toxicity evaluation framework, and compare SGM with existing detoxification techniques. Experiments on open-source MLLMs show that SGM mitigates toxicity in standard and adversarial conditions, cutting harmful rates from 48.2\% to 2.5\% while preserving fluency and multimodal reasoning. SGM is extensible, and its combined defenses, denoted as SGM*, integrate with existing detoxification methods for stronger safety performance, providing an interpretable, low-cost solution for toxicity-controlled multimodal generation.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SGM, a white-box neuron-level intervention method for multimodal large language models to reduce toxicity while preserving capabilities.
AI.motivation: Multimodal LLMs inherit toxic, biased, and NSFW content from their training data, posing safety risks that current training-free detoxification methods, especially under adversarial triggers, cannot adequately address.
AI.method: The authors design SGM, a neuron-level multimodal intervention that identifies toxic expert neurons and applies expertise-weighted soft suppression to recalibrate them without updating model parameters. They also build MM-TOXIC-QA, a multimodal toxicity evaluation benchmark, and compare SGM with existing detoxification approaches.
AI.result: On open-source multimodal LLMs, SGM significantly reduces harmful output rates—e.g., from 48.2% to 2.5%—while maintaining fluency and multimodal reasoning. They further show SGM can be combined with other detox techniques (SGM*) for stronger safety.
AI.conclusion: SGM offers an interpretable, low-cost, and extensible white-box mechanism to control toxicity in multimodal generation, effective in both standard and adversarial settings and complementary to existing detoxification methods.

title: Bilateral Spatial Reasoning about Street Networks: Graph-based RAG with Qualitative Spatial Representations
summary: This paper deals with improving the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLM) to provide route instructions for pedestrian wayfinders by means of qualitative spatial relations.

AI.tldr: The paper aims to enhance LLMs so they can give better walking directions using qualitative spatial descriptions (e.g., 'next to', 'in front of') instead of just precise coordinates.
AI.motivation: Existing LLMs are not yet reliable at producing usable pedestrian navigation instructions in real-world urban environments. Human wayfinding often relies on qualitative spatial relations and landmarks rather than exact coordinates or turn-by-turn numerical data, so there is a gap between how LLMs describe routes and how people naturally navigate.
AI.method: The authors propose techniques (likely data representations, prompts, or model adaptations) that encode and use qualitative spatial relations (like topological, directional, and distance relations) when generating route instructions for pedestrians, instead of or in addition to quantitative geospatial data.
AI.result: The improved LLM approach can generate route instructions that are more aligned with human wayfinding strategies, using natural qualitative spatial relations to describe pedestrian routes more effectively than baseline LLM outputs.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging qualitative spatial relations in LLMs enhances their ability to act as pedestrian navigation assistants, bringing machine-generated route descriptions closer to human-like, cognitively meaningful instructions.

title: The Meta-Prompting Protocol: Orchestrating LLMs via Adversarial Feedback Loops
summary: The transition of Large Language Models (LLMs) from stochastic chat interfaces to reliable software components necessitates a fundamental re-engineering of interaction paradigms. Current methodologies, predominantly heuristic-based "prompt engineering," fail to provide the deterministic guarantees required for mission-critical applications. We introduce the Meta-Prompting Protocol, a rigorous theoretical framework that formalizes the orchestration of LLMs as a programmable, self-optimizing system. Central to this protocol is the Adversarial Trinity, a tripartite topology comprising a Generator (P), an Auditor (A), and an Optimizer (O). By treating natural language instructions as differentiable variables within a semantic computation graph and utilizing textual critiques as gradients, this architecture mitigates hallucination and prevents model collapse. We demonstrate the theoretical viability of this approach using declarative programming paradigms (DSPy) and automatic textual differentiation (TextGrad), establishing a foundation for "Observable Software Engineering" in the era of probabilistic computing.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a formal protocol (Meta-Prompting Protocol) to turn LLMs from heuristic, chat-like tools into deterministic, reliable software components by orchestrating multiple roles and optimizing prompts systematically.
AI.motivation: Current LLM use relies on ad-hoc prompt engineering, which is insufficient for mission-critical applications that need determinism, robustness against hallucinations, and systematic guarantees. The authors want a principled, programmable way to engineer LLM-based systems.
AI.method: They define the Meta-Prompting Protocol, which models LLM instructions as differentiable variables in a semantic computation graph. The system uses an Adversarial Trinity architecture: a Generator (P) that produces outputs, an Auditor (A) that critiques and checks them, and an Optimizer (O) that updates prompts/instructions using the textual critiques as gradients (via DSPy-like declarative specs and TextGrad-style textual differentiation).
AI.result: They provide a theoretical construction and proof-of-concept that natural-language prompts can be optimized systematically with a meta-protocol, reducing hallucinations and avoiding model collapse. They show how this works conceptually with declarative programming (DSPy) and automatic textual differentiation (TextGrad).
AI.conclusion: LLMs can be elevated from stochastic chatbots to engineered, observable software components by formalizing prompt interaction as an optimizable computation graph with adversarial roles. This sets a foundation for a new paradigm of "Observable Software Engineering" for probabilistic, LLM-centric systems.

title: Outer-Learning Framework for Playing Multi-Player Trick-Taking Card Games: A Case Study in Skat
