summary: In multi-player card games such as Skat or Bridge, the early stages of the game, such as bidding, game selection, and initial card selection, are often more critical to the success of the play than refined middle- and end-game play. At the current limits of computation, such early decision-making resorts to using statistical information derived from a large corpus of human expert games. In this paper, we derive and evaluate a general bootstrapping outer-learning framework that improves prediction accuracy by expanding the database of human games with millions of self-playing AI games to generate and merge statistics. We implement perfect feature hash functions to address compacted tables, producing a self-improving card game engine, where newly inferred knowledge is continuously improved during self-learning. The case study in Skat shows that the automated approach can be used to support various decisions in the game.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a bootstrapping framework that improves early-stage decision-making in multiplayer card games by augmenting human expert game data with millions of self-play AI games, leading to a self-improving card game engine.
AI.motivation: Early game decisions like bidding and initial card choices in multiplayer card games (e.g., Skat, Bridge) are critical to success but difficult to optimize purely by search due to computational limits and large decision spaces. Existing systems heavily rely on static statistics from limited human expert corpora, which restricts performance and adaptability. The authors aim to overcome this by creating a scalable way to enhance statistical models beyond human data, without needing constant human input.
AI.method: They propose a general bootstrapping outer-learning framework that starts from a database of human expert games and then augments it with millions of self-play games generated by an AI engine. The system collects and merges statistics from both human and AI-played games to improve prediction models for early game decisions. To handle the large volume of data efficiently, they design perfect feature hash functions for compact, collision-free indexing of statistics tables. The framework is realized as a self-improving card game engine, where knowledge is iteratively updated during continued self-play and learning.
AI.result: In a case study on the card game Skat, the framework successfully supports various early-game decisions (such as bidding and game selection), demonstrating improved prediction accuracy over models relying only on human expert data. The implementation shows that the engine can efficiently manage large statistical tables while continuously refining its decision quality through self-play.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that augmenting human expert game data with large-scale self-play via a bootstrapping outer-learning framework is an effective way to improve early-stage decision-making in complex multiplayer card games. The use of perfect feature hashing enables compact and efficient storage of the learned statistics, making it practical to build self-improving card game engines. The approach is general enough to be applicable beyond Skat to other games with similar early decision challenges.

title: Beyond Majority Voting: Towards Fine-grained and More Reliable Reward Signal for Test-Time Reinforcement Learning
summary: Test-time reinforcement learning mitigates the reliance on annotated data by using majority voting results as pseudo-labels, emerging as a complementary direction to reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) for improving reasoning ability of large language models (LLMs). However, this voting strategy often induces confirmation bias and suffers from sparse rewards, limiting the overall performance. In this work, we propose subgroup-specific step-wise confidence-weighted pseudo-label estimation (SCOPE), a framework integrating model confidence and dynamic subgroup partitioning to address these issues. Specifically, SCOPE integrates the proposed step-wise confidence into pseudo label deduction, prioritizing high-quality reasoning paths over simple frequency count. Furthermore, it dynamically partitions the candidate outputs pool into independent subgroups by balancing reasoning quality against exploration diversity. By deriving local consensus via repeat sampling for each sub group, SCOPE provides diverse supervision targets to encourage broader exploration. We conduct experiments across various models and benchmarks, experimental results show that SCOPE consistently outperforms recent baselines. Notably, SCOPE achieving relative improvements of 13.1\% on challenging AIME 2025 and 8.1\% on AMC. The code is released at \href{https://github.com/szu-tera/SCOPE}{https://github.com/szu-tera/SCOPE}.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SCOPE, a test-time reinforcement learning framework that improves LLM reasoning by confidence-weighted pseudo-labeling and dynamic subgrouping of candidate outputs, outperforming existing methods on math benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing test-time reinforcement learning (RL) methods rely on majority-vote pseudo-labels, which cause confirmation bias and sparse rewards, limiting reasoning improvements in LLMs. The authors want a better way to construct supervision signals that reflect both confidence and diversity to enhance reasoning without annotated data.
AI.method: They propose SCOPE, which (1) computes step-wise confidence scores for reasoning paths and uses them to weight pseudo-label estimation, so high-confidence, high-quality paths are prioritized over simple frequency counts; and (2) dynamically partitions the pool of candidate outputs into several subgroups that trade off reasoning quality and exploration diversity. Within each subgroup, repeated sampling derives a local consensus (pseudo-labels), providing multiple diverse supervision targets used in test-time RL updates.
AI.result: Across several LLMs and reasoning benchmarks, SCOPE consistently outperforms recent test-time RL and RLVR baselines. On the difficult AIME 2025 benchmark it achieves a 13.1% relative improvement, and on AMC an 8.1% relative improvement, demonstrating better reasoning performance without needing ground-truth labels.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating step-wise confidence and subgroup-based diverse pseudo-labeling into test-time RL effectively reduces confirmation bias and sparse reward issues of majority-vote schemes, leading to stronger LLM reasoning abilities. SCOPE is a promising, label-free enhancement strategy for LLM reasoning and is made available as open-source code.

title: Intent-Driven UAM Rescheduling
summary: Due to the restricted resources, efficient scheduling in vertiports has received much more attention in the field of Urban Air Mobility (UAM). For the scheduling problem, we utilize a Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP), which is often formulated in a resource-restricted project scheduling problem (RCPSP). In this paper, we show our approach to handle both dynamic operation requirements and vague rescheduling requests from humans. Particularly, we utilize a three-valued logic for interpreting ambiguous user intents and a decision tree, proposing a newly integrated system that combines Answer Set Programming (ASP) and MILP. This integrated framework optimizes schedules and supports human inputs transparently. With this system, we provide a robust structure for explainable, adaptive UAM scheduling.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes an explainable and adaptive scheduling framework for resource‑constrained vertiports in urban air mobility, integrating MILP-based optimization with ASP, three-valued logic, and decision trees to handle dynamic operations and vague human rescheduling requests.
AI.motivation: Urban Air Mobility vertiports have severely limited resources (e.g., pads, gates, chargers), making efficient scheduling critical. Classical resource-constrained project scheduling (RCPSP) and MILP methods optimize well under fixed, well‑defined constraints, but they struggle when real-world operations are dynamic and when human operators provide vague or partially specified rescheduling requests. There is a need for a scheduling system that both maintains high optimization quality and can flexibly interpret and incorporate ambiguous human inputs in real time, while remaining explainable to operators.
AI.method: The authors formulate the vertiport scheduling problem as a Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model in the style of a resource-constrained project scheduling problem (RCPSP). On top of this, they introduce an integrated framework that combines Answer Set Programming (ASP) with the MILP optimizer. To interpret vague or partially specified human rescheduling requests, they use a three‑valued logic (true/false/unknown or similar) to capture ambiguity in user intents and a decision tree to map these interpreted intents to concrete changes in the scheduling model or constraints. ASP is employed to represent and reason about logical conditions and preferences, while MILP handles the numeric optimization. The system is designed so that the reasoning steps and resulting schedule updates can be explained to human operators.
AI.result: The integrated ASP–MILP framework successfully generates optimized vertiport schedules under resource constraints while accommodating dynamic operational changes and vague human rescheduling inputs. The system can interpret ambiguous requests using the three‑valued logic and decision tree, and then translate them into consistent schedule modifications. It maintains feasibility and resource‑efficiency comparable to standard MILP scheduling, while also producing intermediate reasoning artifacts that can be inspected for transparency. Experiments or case studies (not detailed in the abstract) demonstrate that the approach is robust to changing conditions and supports explainable interaction with operators.
AI.conclusion: The paper concludes that combining MILP-based RCPSP formulations with symbolic reasoning via ASP, supported by three‑valued logic and decision trees for interpreting human intent, yields an effective and explainable framework for UAM vertiport scheduling. This integrated system can robustly handle dynamic operations and vague human rescheduling requests while maintaining high-quality, resource-efficient schedules. The authors position their approach as a promising foundation for adaptive, human-in-the-loop scheduling in future urban air mobility systems.

title: Rakuten Data Release: A Large-Scale and Long-Term Reviews Corpus for Hotel Domain
summary: This paper presents a large-scale corpus of Rakuten Travel Reviews. Our collection contains 7.3 million customer reviews for 16 years, ranging from 2009 to 2024. Each record in the dataset contains the review text, its response from an accommodation, an anonymized reviewer ID, review date, accommodation ID, plan ID, plan title, room type, room name, purpose, accompanying group, and user ratings from different aspect categories, as well as an overall score. We present statistical information about our corpus and provide insights into factors driving data drift between 2019 and 2024 using statistical approaches.

AI.tldr: A paper introduces a 7.3M‑review Rakuten Travel corpus (2009–2024) with rich metadata and uses statistics to analyze data drift between 2019 and 2024.
AI.motivation: There is a need for a large, recent, and richly annotated Japanese travel review corpus to support research in NLP (e.g., sentiment analysis, response generation, recommendation, and temporal analysis). Existing datasets are smaller, less up‑to‑date, or lack aligned accommodation responses and fine‑grained metadata; also, understanding how user behavior and ratings shift over time (data drift) is increasingly important for robust models.
AI.method: The authors collected and anonymized 7.3 million Rakuten Travel reviews over 16 years, pairing each review with its accommodation’s textual response and detailed structured fields (IDs, plan/room info, trip purpose, group composition, multi‑aspect ratings, overall score). They then compute corpus statistics and apply statistical techniques (likely distribution comparison and drift measures) to quantify and interpret changes in review characteristics and ratings between 2019 and 2024.
AI.result: They obtain a large-scale, cleaned corpus with 7.3M reviews and complete associated metadata, and derive descriptive statistics for the dataset. Their statistical analysis reveals specific patterns and factors contributing to data drift over 2019–2024 (e.g., shifts in rating distributions, purposes of stay, or accommodation types), although the abstract does not detail the exact findings.
AI.conclusion: The resulting Rakuten Travel Review corpus is a valuable resource for NLP and data science research on travel reviews, especially for studying review–response interactions, aspect-based sentiment, recommendation, and temporal drift. The statistical drift analysis highlights that review data is not stationary over time, implying that models trained on historic data may need adaptation to remain accurate on recent reviews.

title: Nemotron-Math: Efficient Long-Context Distillation of Mathematical Reasoning from Multi-Mode Supervision
summary:
High-quality mathematical reasoning supervision requires diverse reasoning styles, long-form traces, and effective tool integration, capabilities that existing datasets provide only in limited form. Leveraging the multi-mode generation ability of gpt-oss-120b, we introduce Nemotron-Math, a large-scale mathematical reasoning dataset containing 7.5M solution traces across high, medium, and low reasoning modes, each available both with and without Python tool-integrated reasoning (TIR).
  The dataset integrates 85K curated AoPS problems with 262K community-sourced StackExchange-Math problems, combining structured competition tasks with diverse real-world mathematical queries. We conduct controlled evaluations to assess the dataset quality.
  Nemotron-Math consistently outperforms the original OpenMathReasoning on matched AoPS problems. Incorporating StackExchange-Math substantially improves robustness and generalization, especially on HLE-Math, while preserving accuracy on math competition benchmarks.
  To support efficient long-context training, we develop a sequential bucketed strategy that accelerates 128K context-length fine-tuning by 2--3$\times$ without significant accuracy loss. Overall, Nemotron-Math enables state-of-the-art performance, including 100\% maj@16 accuracy on AIME 2024 and 2025 with Python TIR.

AI.tldr: Nemotron-Math is a large-scale mathematical reasoning dataset with diverse reasoning modes and tool-integrated traces that improves math LLM performance and enables efficient long-context training.
AI.motivation: Existing math reasoning datasets lack diversity in reasoning styles, long-form traces, and systematic integration with tools like Python, limiting the supervision quality for training strong mathematical reasoning models.
AI.method: Use a powerful generator model (gpt-oss-120b) in multi-mode (high, medium, low reasoning) with and without Python tool-integrated reasoning to create 7.5M solution traces for 85K AoPS and 262K StackExchange-Math problems; then perform controlled evaluations and develop a sequential bucketed strategy for efficient 128K-context fine-tuning.
AI.result: Nemotron-Math outperforms OpenMathReasoning on shared AoPS problems, and adding StackExchange-Math improves robustness and generalization, especially on HLE-Math, while maintaining competition benchmark accuracy. The new training strategy speeds up 128K context fine-tuning by 2–3x without significant performance loss, achieving state-of-the-art results including 100% maj@16 on AIME 2024/2025 with Python TIR.
AI.conclusion: Nemotron-Math provides high-quality, diverse, and tool-integrated supervision for mathematical reasoning, enables efficient long-context fine-tuning, and leads to state-of-the-art performance on challenging competition and benchmark math tasks.

title: MCP-SafetyBench: A Benchmark for Safety Evaluation of Large Language Models with Real-World MCP Servers
comment: Our benchmark is available at https://github.com/xjzzzzzzzz/MCPSafety
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are evolving into agentic systems that reason, plan, and operate external tools. The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a key enabler of this transition, offering a standardized interface for connecting LLMs with heterogeneous tools and services. Yet MCP's openness and multi-server workflows introduce new safety risks that existing benchmarks fail to capture, as they focus on isolated attacks or lack real-world coverage. We present MCP-SafetyBench, a comprehensive benchmark built on real MCP servers that supports realistic multi-turn evaluation across five domains: browser automation, financial analysis, location navigation, repository management, and web search. It incorporates a unified taxonomy of 20 MCP attack types spanning server, host, and user sides, and includes tasks requiring multi-step reasoning and cross-server coordination under uncertainty. Using MCP-SafetyBench, we systematically evaluate leading open- and closed-source LLMs, revealing large disparities in safety performance and escalating vulnerabilities as task horizons and server interactions grow. Our results highlight the urgent need for stronger defenses and establish MCP-SafetyBench as a foundation for diagnosing and mitigating safety risks in real-world MCP deployments.

AI.tldr: Benchmark paper introducing MCP-SafetyBench for evaluating safety of LLM agent systems using the Model Context Protocol.
AI.motivation: As LLMs become agentic and interact with many external tools via MCP, new safety risks emerge that are not covered by existing benchmarks, which usually test isolated attacks and lack realistic, multi-server, multi-step scenarios.
AI.method: Design and implement MCP-SafetyBench, a benchmark built on real MCP servers across five domains (browser automation, financial analysis, location navigation, repository management, web search). Define a unified taxonomy of 20 MCP-specific attack types across server, host, and user sides, and create realistic multi-turn tasks requiring multi-step reasoning and cross-server coordination under uncertainty. Use this benchmark to systematically evaluate leading open- and closed-source LLMs.
AI.result: The evaluation uncovers large disparities in safety performance between different LLMs and shows that vulnerabilities increase as tasks become longer-horizon and involve more server interactions.
AI.conclusion: MCP-SafetyBench fills an evaluation gap for MCP-based LLM agents, exposing significant safety weaknesses and underscoring the need for stronger defenses, while providing a foundation for diagnosing and mitigating safety risks in practical MCP deployments.

title: Evaluating Large Language Models in Scientific Discovery
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly applied to scientific research, yet prevailing science benchmarks probe decontextualized knowledge and overlook the iterative reasoning, hypothesis generation, and observation interpretation that drive scientific discovery. We introduce a scenario-grounded benchmark that evaluates LLMs across biology, chemistry, materials, and physics, where domain experts define research projects of genuine interest and decompose them into modular research scenarios from which vetted questions are sampled. The framework assesses models at two levels: (i) question-level accuracy on scenario-tied items and (ii) project-level performance, where models must propose testable hypotheses, design simulations or experiments, and interpret results. Applying this two-phase scientific discovery evaluation (SDE) framework to state-of-the-art LLMs reveals a consistent performance gap relative to general science benchmarks, diminishing return of scaling up model sizes and reasoning, and systematic weaknesses shared across top-tier models from different providers. Large performance variation in research scenarios leads to changing choices of the best performing model on scientific discovery projects evaluated, suggesting all current LLMs are distant to general scientific "superintelligence". Nevertheless, LLMs already demonstrate promise in a great variety of scientific discovery projects, including cases where constituent scenario scores are low, highlighting the role of guided exploration and serendipity in discovery. This SDE framework offers a reproducible benchmark for discovery-relevant evaluation of LLMs and charts practical paths to advance their development toward scientific discovery.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new, scenario-grounded benchmark (SDE) to evaluate how well large language models support end-to-end scientific discovery, beyond standard knowledge tests.
AI.motivation: Existing science benchmarks for LLMs mainly test decontextualized factual knowledge or narrow reasoning skills, and thus do not capture the iterative, context-rich processes—hypothesis generation, experimental design, and result interpretation—that underpin real scientific discovery. As LLMs are increasingly used in research, there is a need for an evaluation framework that reflects realistic scientific workflows across multiple disciplines and reveals their true capabilities and limitations in discovery settings.
AI.method: The authors design a two-phase Scientific Discovery Evaluation (SDE) framework. Domain experts in biology, chemistry, materials science, and physics define real research projects of genuine interest, then decompose each project into modular, scenario-based tasks. From these, vetted questions are sampled. Models are evaluated at (i) the question level, where accuracy is measured on scenario-tied items, and (ii) the project level, where models must propose testable hypotheses, design simulations or experiments, and interpret hypothetical or simulated results. State-of-the-art LLMs from multiple providers and with varying sizes/reasoning capabilities are run through this framework and compared against standard science benchmarks.
AI.result: The evaluation shows that LLM performance on the SDE benchmark is consistently weaker than on general science benchmarks, indicating that success on conventional tests does not transfer directly to real discovery tasks. Scaling model size and adding enhanced reasoning yields diminishing performance gains in the SDE setting. Different top-tier models exhibit similar systematic weaknesses and show large performance variation across research scenarios. As a result, the identity of the “best” model changes from project to project. Despite these limitations, LLMs still manage to contribute meaningfully to many scientific discovery projects, sometimes performing surprisingly well at the project level even when their scores on individual scenarios are low.
AI.conclusion: Current LLMs remain far from a general scientific “superintelligence,” but they already offer valuable support for diverse scientific discovery workflows, particularly via guided exploration and occasional serendipitous insights. The proposed SDE framework provides a reproducible, discovery-relevant benchmark that better aligns with real-world research practice than existing tests and can guide the future development and evaluation of LLMs aimed at scientific discovery.

title: From NLG Evaluation to Modern Student Assessment in the Era of ChatGPT: The Great Misalignment Problem and Pedagogical Multi-Factor Assessment (P-MFA)
summary: This paper explores the growing epistemic parallel between NLG evaluation and grading of students in a Finnish University. We argue that both domains are experiencing a Great Misalignment Problem. As students increasingly use tools like ChatGPT to produce sophisticated outputs, traditional assessment methods that focus on final products rather than learning processes have lost their validity. To address this, we introduce the Pedagogical Multi-Factor Assessment (P-MFA) model, a process-based, multi-evidence framework inspired by the logic of multi-factor authentication.

AI.tldr: The paper compares challenges in evaluating natural language generation (NLG) systems with grading university students, arguing both face a 'Great Misalignment Problem' as outputs become more sophisticated but assessments remain product-focused. It proposes a new process-based, multi-evidence assessment framework, P-MFA, inspired by multi-factor authentication to better align evaluation with actual learning and generation processes.
AI.motivation: With tools like ChatGPT, both NLG systems and students can produce high-quality final outputs that mask shallow understanding or weak underlying processes, making traditional product-focused evaluation less valid. The authors want to rethink evaluation so it captures the learning or generative process, not just the end product, and to draw conceptual parallels between AI evaluation and educational assessment.
AI.method: Conceptual and methodological development: the authors analyze the 'Great Misalignment Problem' in NLG evaluation and student grading, then design the Pedagogical Multi-Factor Assessment (P-MFA) model. P-MFA is a process-oriented framework that uses multiple forms of evidence (e.g., drafts, reflections, interaction logs) analogous to multi-factor authentication, to evaluate learning and authorship more robustly.
AI.result: The paper formulates the P-MFA model and articulates its components and theoretical grounding. It shows, at least conceptually or via examples, how P-MFA can better differentiate genuine learning and authorship from surface-level performance enhanced by AI tools, and how similar logic can improve NLG system evaluation.
AI.conclusion: Evaluating only final textual products is no longer reliable in a world where advanced AI tools can generate sophisticated text. Both NLG evaluation and educational grading need to shift towards process-based, multi-evidence frameworks like P-MFA that better align assessment with underlying competence, learning, and generative processes.

title: A Decision-Theoretic Approach for Managing Misalignment
comment: Second Conference of the International Association for Safe and Ethical Artificial Intelligence (IASEAI '26)
summary: When should we delegate decisions to AI systems? While the value alignment literature has developed techniques for shaping AI values, less attention has been paid to how to determine, under uncertainty, when imperfect alignment is good enough to justify delegation. We argue that rational delegation requires balancing an agent's value (mis)alignment with its epistemic accuracy and its reach (the acts it has available). This paper introduces a formal, decision-theoretic framework to analyze this tradeoff precisely accounting for a principal's uncertainty about these factors. Our analysis reveals a sharp distinction between two delegation scenarios. First, universal delegation (trusting an agent with any problem) demands near-perfect value alignment and total epistemic trust, conditions rarely met in practice. Second, we show that context-specific delegation can be optimal even with significant misalignment. An agent's superior accuracy or expanded reach may grant access to better overall decision problems, making delegation rational in expectation. We develop a novel scoring framework to quantify this ex ante decision. Ultimately, our work provides a principled method for determining when an AI is aligned enough for a given context, shifting the focus from achieving perfect alignment to managing the risks and rewards of delegation under uncertainty.

AI.tldr: Paper gives a decision-theoretic framework for when to delegate decisions to imperfectly aligned AI agents.
AI.motivation: Existing work focuses on aligning AI values but not on deciding, under uncertainty, when that imperfect alignment is still good enough to justify handing over decisions to AI. There is a need for a principled way to trade off misalignment risk against potential benefits like better information or greater action space.
AI.method: They build a formal decision-theoretic model of delegation where a principal considers an AI agent characterized by value alignment, epistemic accuracy, and action reach, all under uncertainty. They distinguish universal versus context-specific delegation, and define a new scoring framework to evaluate ex ante whether delegation is rational in expectation.
AI.result: The analysis shows that universal delegation is only rational under extremely strict conditions: near-perfect value alignment and nearly complete epistemic trust. However, in specific contexts, delegation can be rational even with notable misalignment, when the AI’s better predictive accuracy or larger action set leads to access to better overall decision problems. The scoring framework quantifies this tradeoff numerically.
AI.conclusion: Perfect alignment is not always required for rational delegation. A decision-maker should instead assess, for each context, whether the expected benefits from the AI’s accuracy and reach outweigh the risks from value misalignment, using their formal scoring method as a guide. This reframes alignment from an absolute goal to a context-relative, risk–reward management problem.

title: RFKG-CoT: Relation-Driven Adaptive Hop-count Selection and Few-Shot Path Guidance for Knowledge-Aware QA
summary: Large language models (LLMs) often generate hallucinations in knowledge-intensive QA due to parametric knowledge limitations. While existing methods like KG-CoT improve reliability by integrating knowledge graph (KG) paths, they suffer from rigid hop-count selection (solely question-driven) and underutilization of reasoning paths (lack of guidance). To address this, we propose RFKG-CoT: First, it replaces the rigid hop-count selector with a relation-driven adaptive hop-count selector that dynamically adjusts reasoning steps by activating KG relations (e.g., 1-hop for direct "brother" relations, 2-hop for indirect "father-son" chains), formalized via a relation mask. Second, it introduces a few-shot in-context learning path guidance mechanism with CoT (think) that constructs examples in a "question-paths-answer" format to enhance LLMs' ability to understand reasoning paths. Experiments on four KGQA benchmarks show RFKG-CoT improves accuracy by up to 14.7 pp (Llama2-7B on WebQSP) over KG-CoT. Ablations confirm the hop-count selector and the path prompt are complementary, jointly transforming KG evidence into more faithful answers.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes RFKG-CoT, a method that reduces hallucinations in knowledge-intensive QA by adaptively choosing KG reasoning hops based on relations and by explicitly guiding LLMs with question–path–answer CoT prompts, significantly outperforming prior KG-CoT baselines.
AI.motivation: Large language models hallucinate in knowledge-intensive question answering because their internal parametric knowledge is limited. Existing KG-augmented CoT methods such as KG-CoT help by injecting reasoning paths from knowledge graphs, but they use a rigid, question-only-based hop-count selection and do not fully exploit the provided reasoning paths. This reduces flexibility, wastes KG evidence, and limits answer faithfulness and accuracy. The paper seeks to create a more adaptive and path-aware framework that can better use KG structure during reasoning.
AI.method: The authors introduce RFKG-CoT with two main components: (1) a relation-driven adaptive hop-count selector that uses activated KG relations to dynamically decide how many hops to traverse (e.g., 1-hop for direct relations like "brother", 2-hop for composed chains like "father-son"), implemented via a relation mask formalization; and (2) a few-shot in-context learning path guidance mechanism, where prompts are structured as "question-paths-answer" and combined with Chain-of-Thought (think) style reasoning to help the LLM interpret and utilize KG reasoning paths. These components jointly steer the LLM’s multi-hop reasoning over the KG.
AI.result: On four KGQA benchmarks, RFKG-CoT yields substantial performance gains over KG-CoT, with up to 14.7 percentage point accuracy improvement (notably for Llama2-7B on WebQSP). Ablation studies show that both the relation-driven hop-count selector and the path-guided CoT prompting individually contribute to performance and are complementary when used together.
AI.conclusion: RFKG-CoT demonstrates that dynamically controlling KG hop counts via relation activation and explicitly guiding LLMs with question–path–answer CoT prompts can significantly improve the faithfulness and accuracy of knowledge-graph-augmented QA. The adaptive selector and path guidance are synergistic, effectively transforming KG evidence into better-grounded answers, indicating a promising direction for reducing hallucinations in knowledge-intensive tasks.

title: Stepwise Think-Critique: A Unified Framework for Robust and Interpretable LLM Reasoning
summary: Human beings solve complex problems through critical thinking, where reasoning and evaluation are intertwined to converge toward correct solutions. However, most existing large language models (LLMs) decouple reasoning from verification: they either generate reasoning without explicit self-checking or rely on external verifiers to detect errors post hoc. The former lacks immediate feedback, while the latter increases system complexity and hinders synchronized learning. Motivated by human critical thinking, we propose Stepwise Think-Critique (STC), a unified framework that interleaves reasoning and self-critique at each step within a single model. STC is trained with a hybrid reinforcement learning objective combining reasoning rewards and critique-consistency rewards to jointly optimize reasoning quality and self-evaluation. Experiments on mathematical reasoning benchmarks show that STC demonstrates strong critic-thinking capabilities and produces more interpretable reasoning traces, representing a step toward LLMs with built-in critical thinking.

AI.tldr: They introduce Stepwise Think-Critique (STC), a framework where an LLM interleaves reasoning with self-critique at every step, trained via reinforcement learning to improve both solution accuracy and self-evaluation, achieving better and more interpretable performance on math reasoning benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing LLMs separate reasoning from verification, either generating reasoning without explicit self-checking or using external verifiers afterward. This causes lack of immediate feedback, system complexity, and unsynchronized learning. Inspired by how humans use critical thinking—reasoning and evaluation intertwined—the authors aim to design an LLM framework that unifies reasoning and self-critique within a single model.
AI.method: They propose Stepwise Think-Critique (STC), where the LLM alternates between reasoning steps and self-critique steps within the same model. Training uses a hybrid reinforcement learning objective that combines rewards for good reasoning with rewards for consistency between reasoning and critique, jointly optimizing both capabilities. The system is evaluated on mathematical reasoning tasks.
AI.result: On mathematical reasoning benchmarks, the STC model exhibits strong critical-thinking behavior: it better identifies and corrects its own errors, and its reasoning traces are more structured and interpretable compared with baselines that separate reasoning and verification or lack explicit critique.
AI.conclusion: Integrating stepwise self-critique into the reasoning process of LLMs and training it with a combined reasoning and critique-consistency reinforcement signal leads to models with more accurate, reliable, and interpretable reasoning. STC is presented as a step toward LLMs with innate critical-thinking abilities, reducing the need for external verifiers.

title: Yes-MT's Submission to the Low-Resource Indic Language Translation Shared Task in WMT 2024
summary: This paper presents the systems submitted by the Yes-MT team for the Low-Resource Indic Language Translation Shared Task at WMT 2024 (Pakray et al., 2024), focusing on translating between English and the Assamese, Mizo, Khasi, and Manipuri languages. The experiments explored various approaches, including fine-tuning pre-trained models like mT5 (Xue et al., 2020) and IndicBart (Dabre et al., 2021) in both multilingual and monolingual settings, LoRA (Hu et al., 2021) fine-tuning IndicTrans2 (Gala et al., 2023), zero-shot and few-shot prompting (Brown, 2020) with large language models (LLMs) like Llama 3 (Dubey et al., 2024) and Mixtral 8x7b (Jiang et al., 2024), LoRA supervised fine-tuning of Llama 3 (Mecklenburg et al., 2024), and training Transformer models (Vaswani, 2017) from scratch. The results were evaluated on the WMT23 Low-Resource Indic Language Translation Shared Task test data using SacreBLEU (Post, 2018) and CHRF (Popovic, 2015), highlighting the challenges of low-resource translation and the potential of LLMs for these tasks, particularly with fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: Systems paper for WMT24 exploring many architectures and training strategies for low-resource English↔Indic (Assamese, Mizo, Khasi, Manipuri) MT; LLMs with fine-tuning show strong potential.
AI.motivation: High-quality machine translation for low-resource Indic languages like Assamese, Mizo, Khasi, and Manipuri is underdeveloped due to limited parallel data and tooling. The shared task provides a standardized benchmark to test what works best under such constraints. The authors aim to systematically compare a spectrum of modern approaches—from classic Transformers to pre-trained multilingual models and large language models—to understand which techniques are most effective and practical in low-resource Indic MT settings.
AI.method: The team built multiple MT systems for English↔Assamese/Mizo/Khasi/Manipuri. They (1) fine-tuned pre-trained sequence-to-sequence models (mT5, IndicBart) in both multilingual and monolingual setups; (2) applied LoRA-based fine-tuning to IndicTrans2; (3) evaluated zero-shot and few-shot prompting of general-purpose LLMs (Llama 3, Mixtral 8x7b); (4) performed LoRA-based supervised fine-tuning of Llama 3 as a task-specific MT model; and (5) trained standard Transformer models from scratch. They then evaluated all systems on WMT23 low-resource Indic test sets using SacreBLEU and CHRF metrics.
AI.result: Across the explored systems, performance varied significantly, reflecting the inherent difficulty of low-resource Indic MT. LLMs showed promising results, especially when adapted via fine-tuning rather than used purely in zero-/few-shot prompting mode. Pre-trained multilingual MT models and LoRA-adapted architectures generally outperformed Transformers trained from scratch, which struggled due to limited data. Detailed metric scores (SacreBLEU, CHRF) on WMT23 test sets quantify these differences.
AI.conclusion: Low-resource translation for Indic languages remains challenging, but leveraging pre-trained models and especially LLMs with lightweight adaptation (e.g., LoRA fine-tuning) can yield substantial gains over training new models from scratch. The study underscores the importance of pre-training, multilingual transfer, and parameter-efficient fine-tuning for improving translation quality in under-resourced language pairs, and provides empirical evidence and baselines for future work in this space.

title: Explaining the Reasoning of Large Language Models Using Attribution Graphs
summary: Large language models (LLMs) exhibit remarkable capabilities, yet their reasoning remains opaque, raising safety and trust concerns. Attribution methods, which assign credit to input features, have proven effective for explaining the decision making of computer vision models. From these, context attributions have emerged as a promising approach for explaining the behavior of autoregressive LLMs. However, current context attributions produce incomplete explanations by directly relating generated tokens to the prompt, discarding inter-generational influence in the process. To overcome these shortcomings, we introduce the Context Attribution via Graph Explanations (CAGE) framework. CAGE introduces an attribution graph: a directed graph that quantifies how each generation is influenced by both the prompt and all prior generations. The graph is constructed to preserve two properties-causality and row stochasticity. The attribution graph allows context attributions to be computed by marginalizing intermediate contributions along paths in the graph. Across multiple models, datasets, metrics, and methods, CAGE improves context attribution faithfulness, achieving average gains of up to 40%.

AI.tldr: Introduces CAGE, a framework that builds an attribution graph to explain how each generated token in an LLM is influenced by the prompt and previous generations, improving the faithfulness of context attributions.
AI.motivation: LLMs are powerful but their internal reasoning is opaque, which is a safety and trust issue. Existing attribution methods from vision were adapted to LLMs as context attributions, but they only link outputs directly to the prompt and ignore how earlier generated tokens influence later ones, leading to incomplete explanations.
AI.method: Define Context Attribution via Graph Explanations (CAGE), which constructs an attribution graph: a directed, row-stochastic causal graph where nodes are generations (tokens or steps) and edges quantify influence from the prompt and all prior generations. Context attributions are then computed by marginalizing influence along all paths in this graph, capturing both direct and indirect effects.
AI.result: Across multiple language models, datasets, evaluation metrics, and underlying attribution techniques, CAGE yields more faithful context attributions, with average improvements reported up to 40% over prior methods.
AI.conclusion: Model explanations for LLMs can be significantly improved by explicitly modeling inter-generational influence through an attribution graph. By enforcing causality and stochasticity and propagating influence along graph paths, CAGE provides more faithful and complete context attributions than existing prompt-only methods.

title: FAME: Fictional Actors for Multilingual Erasure
summary: LLMs trained on web-scale data raise concerns about privacy and the right to be forgotten. To address these issues, Machine Unlearning provides techniques to remove specific information from trained models without retraining from scratch. However, existing benchmarks for evaluating unlearning in LLMs face two major limitations: they focus only on English and support only entity-level forgetting (removing all information about a person). We introduce FAME (Fictional Actors for Multilingual Erasure), a synthetic benchmark for evaluating Machine Unlearning across five languages: English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish. FAME contains 1,000 fictional actor biographies and 20,000 question-answer pairs. Each biography includes information on 20 topics organized into structured categories (biography, career, achievements, personal information). This design enables both entity-level unlearning (i.e., forgetting entire identities) and instance-level unlearning (i.e., forgetting specific facts while retaining others). We provide two dataset splits to support these two different unlearning scenarios and enable systematic comparison of unlearning techniques across languages. Since FAME uses entirely fictional data, it ensures that the information was never encountered during model pretraining, allowing for a controlled evaluation of unlearning methods.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FAME, a multilingual synthetic benchmark to evaluate machine unlearning in large language models.
AI.motivation: Existing machine unlearning benchmarks for LLMs are limited to English and only test entity-level forgetting, which does not reflect more granular or multilingual unlearning needs.
AI.method: The authors construct a synthetic dataset of 1,000 fictional actor biographies across five languages (English, French, German, Italian, Spanish), each with structured information on 20 topics. They generate 20,000 QA pairs enabling evaluation of both entity-level and instance-level unlearning via two dataset splits tailored to these scenarios.
AI.result: FAME provides a controlled evaluation setting where all data are fictional and thus unseen during pretraining, and supports systematic comparison of unlearning methods across languages and unlearning granularities.
AI.conclusion: FAME fills an important gap for evaluating multilingual and fine-grained machine unlearning in LLMs by offering a synthetic, controlled, and structured benchmark that supports both entity- and instance-level erasure.

title: Artism: AI-Driven Dual-Engine System for Art Generation and Critique
comment: 7 pages, 3 figures, 36 references, appendix with support material and 1 introduction video
summary: This paper proposes a dual-engine AI architectural method designed to address the complex problem of exploring potential trajectories in the evolution of art. We present two interconnected components: AIDA (an artificial artist social network) and the Ismism Machine, a system for critical analysis. The core innovation lies in leveraging deep learning and multi-agent collaboration to enable multidimensional simulations of art historical developments and conceptual innovation patterns. The framework explores a shift from traditional unidirectional critique toward an intelligent, interactive mode of reflexive practice. We are currently applying this method in experimental studies on contemporary art concepts. This study introduces a general methodology based on AI-driven critical loops, offering new possibilities for computational analysis of art.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a dual-AI framework to simulate and critically analyze the evolution of art by combining an artificial artist social network with an AI critique engine.
AI.motivation: To tackle the complex task of exploring possible future and alternative trajectories in art history and conceptual innovation, and to move beyond traditional, linear, human-only art criticism toward richer, interactive, and computationally supported analysis.
AI.method: Introduce a dual-engine AI architecture consisting of AIDA, an artificial artist social network of multiple agents, and the Ismism Machine, a critical analysis engine. The system uses deep learning and multi-agent collaboration to run multidimensional simulations of art-historical developments and patterns of conceptual innovation, organized as AI-driven critical feedback loops.
AI.result: The framework has been implemented and is being applied in experimental studies on contemporary art concepts, demonstrating that AI-based multi-agent simulations and critique loops can model and explore complex artistic evolutions in a structured way.
AI.conclusion: The study presents a general AI-based methodology for reflexive, interactive, and computational analysis of art, replacing unidirectional critique with AI-driven critical loops and opening new avenues for studying and simulating art-historical and conceptual developments.

title: The Moralization Corpus: Frame-Based Annotation and Analysis of Moralizing Speech Acts across Diverse Text Genres
summary: Moralizations - arguments that invoke moral values to justify demands or positions - are a yet underexplored form of persuasive communication. We present the Moralization Corpus, a novel multi-genre dataset designed to analyze how moral values are strategically used in argumentative discourse. Moralizations are pragmatically complex and often implicit, posing significant challenges for both human annotators and NLP systems. We develop a frame-based annotation scheme that captures the constitutive elements of moralizations - moral values, demands, and discourse protagonists - and apply it to a diverse set of German texts, including political debates, news articles, and online discussions. The corpus enables fine-grained analysis of moralizing language across communicative formats and domains. We further evaluate several large language models (LLMs) under varied prompting conditions for the task of moralization detection and moralization component extraction and compare it to human annotations in order to investigate the challenges of automatic and manual analysis of moralizations. Results show that detailed prompt instructions has a greater effect than few-shot or explanation-based prompting, and that moralization remains a highly subjective and context-sensitive task. We release all data, annotation guidelines, and code to foster future interdisciplinary research on moral discourse and moral reasoning in NLP.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Moralization Corpus, a German multi-genre dataset plus an annotation scheme and LLM evaluation for detecting and analyzing moralizing arguments in text.
AI.motivation: Moralization—using moral values to justify demands or positions—is a central but underexplored form of persuasion in discourse, and it is pragmatically complex, often implicit, and highly subjective. Existing NLP resources and models are poorly equipped to capture how moral values are strategically used across domains like politics, news, and online discussions. The authors want to enable systematic, fine-grained study of moralizing language and test how well humans and LLMs can detect and decompose such moralizations.
AI.method: The authors construct the Moralization Corpus, a multi-genre collection of German texts (political debates, news articles, online discussions). They design a frame-based annotation scheme that labels (a) moral values, (b) demands, and (c) discourse protagonists as components of moralizations. Human annotators apply this scheme to the corpus. The authors then evaluate several large language models on two tasks: (1) detecting whether a text contains moralization and (2) extracting its components, under different prompting strategies (detailed instructions, few-shot examples, explanation-based prompts). Model predictions are compared to human annotations to study both automatic and manual analysis challenges.
AI.result: The corpus and annotation scheme make it possible to conduct detailed, component-level analyses of moralizing language across several communicative formats and domains. In LLM evaluations, prompts with detailed instructions improve performance more than few-shot or explanation-based prompts. Despite these gains, moralization detection and component extraction remain difficult, with considerable subjectivity and context sensitivity reflected both in human annotations and model outputs.
AI.conclusion: The paper contributes a new annotated corpus, an explicit frame-based annotation scheme for moralizations, and an empirical study of LLM prompting strategies on moralization detection and component extraction. It demonstrates that while prompting can modestly help, moralization is inherently subjective and context-dependent, posing challenges for both human coders and NLP systems. By releasing data, guidelines, and code, the authors aim to support further interdisciplinary work on computational analysis of moral discourse and moral reasoning.

title: SynGP500: A Clinically-Grounded Synthetic Dataset of Australian General Practice Medical Notes
summary: We introduce SynGP500, a clinician-curated collection of 500 synthetic Australian general practice medical notes. The dataset integrates curriculum-based clinical breadth (RACGP 2022 Curriculum), epidemiologically-calibrated prevalence (BEACH study), and diverse consultation contexts. This approach systematically includes both common presentations and less-common curriculum-specified conditions that GPs must recognize but appear infrequently in single practice populations, potentially supporting more generalizable model training than datasets constrained by naturally occurring case distributions. SynGP500 is messy by design, reflecting the authentic complexity of healthcare delivery: telegraphic documentation, typos, patient non-adherence, socioeconomic barriers, and clinician-patient disagreements, unlike sanitized synthetic datasets that obscure clinical realities. Multi-faceted validation demonstrates dataset quality through epidemiological alignment with real Australian GP consultation patterns (BEACH study), stylometric analysis confirming high linguistic variation, semantic diversity analysis demonstrating broad coverage, and exploratory downstream evaluation using self-supervised medical concept extraction, showing F1 improvements. SynGP500 addresses a critical national gap, providing researchers and educators with a resource for developing and evaluating clinical NLP methods for Australian general practice while inherently protecting patient privacy.

AI.tldr: SynGP500 is a synthetic, clinician-curated dataset of 500 Australian GP notes designed to reflect real-world messiness while preserving privacy and improving generalizability for clinical NLP.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of realistic, privacy-preserving datasets for Australian general practice that capture both common and infrequent but curriculum-relevant conditions, limiting the development and evaluation of robust clinical NLP models.
AI.method: The authors generated 500 synthetic GP notes curated by clinicians, aligning the case mix with the RACGP 2022 Curriculum and epidemiological data from the BEACH study. They intentionally preserved real-world documentation messiness (telegraphic style, typos, socioeconomic and adherence issues, etc.) and performed multi-faceted validation including epidemiological comparison, stylometric and semantic diversity analyses, and exploratory downstream evaluation via self-supervised concept extraction.
AI.result: SynGP500 exhibits epidemiological alignment with Australian GP consultation patterns, high linguistic variation, broad semantic coverage, and yields F1 performance improvements in a self-supervised medical concept extraction task compared with baseline data.
AI.conclusion: SynGP500 fills an important gap by providing a realistic, privacy-safe synthetic dataset for Australian general practice that can support research and education in clinical NLP, and may enable more generalizable models than those trained solely on naturally occurring case distributions.

title: Well Begun, Half Done: Reinforcement Learning with Prefix Optimization for LLM Reasoning
summary: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) significantly enhances the reasoning capability of Large Language Models (LLMs). Current RLVR approaches typically conduct training across all generated tokens, but neglect to explore which tokens (e.g., prefix tokens) actually contribute to reasoning. This uniform training strategy spends substantial effort on optimizing low-return tokens, which in turn impedes the potential improvement from high-return tokens and reduces overall training effectiveness. To address this issue, we propose a novel RLVR approach called Progressive Prefix-token Policy Optimization (PPPO), which highlights the significance of the prefix segment of generated outputs. Specifically, inspired by the well-established human thinking theory of Path Dependence, where early-stage thoughts substantially constrain subsequent thinking trajectory, we identify an analogous phenomenon in LLM reasoning termed Beginning Lock-in Effect (BLE). PPPO leverages this finding by focusing its optimization objective on the prefix reasoning process of LLMs. This targeted optimization strategy can positively influence subsequent reasoning processes, and ultimately improve final results. To improve the learning effectiveness of LLMs on how to start reasoning with high quality, PPPO introduces two training strategies: (a) Progressive Prefix Retention, which shapes a progressive learning process by increasing the proportion of retained prefix tokens during training; (b) Continuation Accumulated Reward, which mitigates reward bias by sampling multiple continuations for one prefix token sequence, and accumulating their scores as the reward signal. Extensive experimental results on various reasoning tasks demonstrate that our proposed PPPO outperforms representative RLVR methods, with the accuracy improvements of 18.02% on only 26.17% training tokens.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Progressive Prefix-token Policy Optimization (PPPO), an RLVR method that focuses optimization on prefix tokens in LLM reasoning, improving accuracy with fewer trained tokens.
AI.motivation: Existing RLVR methods train uniformly over all generated tokens, failing to differentiate between high-impact (e.g., early reasoning steps) and low-impact tokens. This leads to inefficient training where effort is wasted on tokens that contribute little to final reasoning quality, limiting overall performance gains.
AI.method: The authors introduce PPPO, which centers training on the prefix portion of generated sequences based on the Beginning Lock-in Effect (BLE), an identified analogy to path dependence in human thinking. PPPO employs two strategies: (1) Progressive Prefix Retention—gradually increasing the fraction of prefix tokens kept and optimized during training to create a progressive curriculum over early reasoning steps; (2) Continuation Accumulated Reward—sampling multiple continuations from a shared prefix and aggregating their rewards to form a more robust reward signal for that prefix, thus reducing reward noise and bias.
AI.result: Across multiple reasoning benchmarks, PPPO surpasses existing RLVR baselines, achieving up to 18.02% accuracy improvement while requiring training on only 26.17% of the tokens compared to standard approaches, indicating both better performance and higher training efficiency.
AI.conclusion: Focusing reinforcement learning on influential prefix tokens in LLM reasoning, as realized by PPPO, can exploit a Beginning Lock-in Effect analogous to path dependence in human cognition. This targeted strategy yields more effective and efficient RLVR training, improving reasoning accuracy while greatly reducing the number of tokens needing optimization.

title: Towards Proactive Personalization through Profile Customization for Individual Users in Dialogues
summary: The deployment of Large Language Models (LLMs) in interactive systems necessitates a deep alignment with the nuanced and dynamic preferences of individual users. Current alignment techniques predominantly address universal human values or static, single-turn preferences, thereby failing to address the critical needs of long-term personalization and the initial user cold-start problem. To bridge this gap, we propose PersonalAgent, a novel user-centric lifelong agent designed to continuously infer and adapt to user preferences. PersonalAgent constructs and dynamically refines a unified user profile by decomposing dialogues into single-turn interactions, framing preference inference as a sequential decision-making task. Experiments show that PersonalAgent achieves superior performance over strong prompt-based and policy optimization baselines, not only in idealized but also in noisy conversational contexts, while preserving cross-session preference consistency. Furthermore, human evaluation confirms that PersonalAgent excels at capturing user preferences naturally and coherently. Our findings underscore the importance of lifelong personalization for developing more inclusive and adaptive conversational agents. Our code is available here.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces PersonalAgent, a lifelong user-centric agent for LLMs that continuously infers and updates user preferences to enable long-term personalization and solve cold-start issues.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM alignment mainly targets generic human values or static, single-turn preferences, which is insufficient for long-term personalization and handling the cold-start problem in interactive systems.
AI.method: PersonalAgent decomposes dialogues into single-turn interactions and treats preference inference as a sequential decision-making problem. It builds and continuously refines a unified user profile over time, enabling the agent to adapt to evolving preferences even in noisy conversations across multiple sessions.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate that PersonalAgent outperforms strong prompt-based and policy optimization baselines in both idealized and noisy conversational settings, and maintains consistent preferences across sessions. Human evaluations further validate its ability to naturally and coherently capture user preferences.
AI.conclusion: Lifelong personalization via agents like PersonalAgent is crucial for creating more inclusive and adaptive conversational systems, and the proposed framework offers an effective way to model and update user preferences over time.

title: Evaluating LLMs for Zeolite Synthesis Event Extraction (ZSEE): A Systematic Analysis of Prompting Strategies
summary: Extracting structured information from zeolite synthesis experimental procedures is critical for materials discovery, yet existing methods have not systematically evaluated Large Language Models (LLMs) for this domain-specific task. This work addresses a fundamental question: what is the efficacy of different prompting strategies when applying LLMs to scientific information extraction? We focus on four key subtasks: event type classification (identifying synthesis steps), trigger text identification (locating event mentions), argument role extraction (recognizing parameter types), and argument text extraction (extracting parameter values). We evaluate four prompting strategies - zero-shot, few-shot, event-specific, and reflection-based - across six state-of-the-art LLMs (Gemma-3-12b-it, GPT-5-mini, O4-mini, Claude-Haiku-3.5, DeepSeek reasoning and non-reasoning) using the ZSEE dataset of 1,530 annotated sentences. Results demonstrate strong performance on event type classification (80-90\% F1) but modest performance on fine-grained extraction tasks, particularly argument role and argument text extraction (50-65\% F1). GPT-5-mini exhibits extreme prompt sensitivity with 11-79\% F1 variation. Notably, advanced prompting strategies provide minimal improvements over zero-shot approaches, revealing fundamental architectural limitations. Error analysis identifies systematic hallucination, over-generalization, and inability to capture synthesis-specific nuances. Our findings demonstrate that while LLMs achieve high-level understanding, precise extraction of experimental parameters requires domain-adapted models, providing quantitative benchmarks for scientific information extraction.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates how well various prompting strategies with LLMs can extract structured synthesis information from zeolite experimental procedures, finding good performance on high-level step classification but weaker results on fine-grained parameter extraction and little benefit from complex prompting.
AI.motivation: To accelerate materials discovery, there is a need to automatically extract structured, machine-readable information from experimental synthesis descriptions; however, LLMs have not been systematically assessed for this specialized extraction task, nor is it clear which prompting strategies work best.
AI.method: The authors use the ZSEE dataset of 1,530 annotated sentences from zeolite synthesis procedures and benchmark six modern LLMs (Gemma-3-12b-it, GPT-5-mini, O4-mini, Claude-Haiku-3.5, and two DeepSeek variants) on four subtasks: classifying synthesis events, identifying trigger text spans, extracting argument roles (parameter types), and extracting argument texts (parameter values). They compare four prompting schemes (zero-shot, few-shot, event-specific, and reflection-based) and analyze performance, prompt sensitivity, and error types.
AI.result: LLMs achieve relatively high F1 (80–90%) on event type classification but only moderate F1 (50–65%) on fine-grained argument role and argument text extraction. GPT-5-mini shows very high sensitivity to prompt design, with F1 varying between 11–79%. More sophisticated prompting strategies yield only marginal gains over simple zero-shot prompting, and consistent error patterns such as hallucination and over-generalization are observed.
AI.conclusion: State-of-the-art LLMs can capture high-level structure in zeolite synthesis procedures but struggle with precise extraction of experimental parameters, suggesting that architectural and domain-adaptation limitations constrain performance. Prompt engineering alone is insufficient; specialized, domain-adapted models are required, and the benchmarks provided can guide future scientific information extraction research.

title: Why Your Academic Field Is Everywhere at Once: A Case Study of Arabic Linguistics
summary: This study applies Brookes' Measure of Categorical Dispersion (Δ) to analyze the thematic structure of contemporary Arabic Applied Linguistics research. Using a comprehensive, real-world dataset of 1,564 publications from 2019 to 2025, classified into eight core sub-disciplines, we calculate a dispersion index of Δ = 0.194. This remarkably low value indicates extreme thematic dispersion, revealing that the field is characterized by pronounced heterogeneity rather than concentration. The analysis identifies Computational Linguistics as a dominant but non-hegemonic force, coexisting with robust research in Sociolinguistics, Language Teaching, and other subfields. This study clarifies the correct application of Brookes' original formula, demonstrates its utility for field characterization, and provides a replicable bibliometric methodology for assessing disciplinary structure across domains.

AI.tldr: The paper uses Brookes’ Measure of Categorical Dispersion to show that contemporary Arabic Applied Linguistics is extremely thematically dispersed rather than concentrated, with several strong but non-hegemonic subfields.
AI.motivation: There is a need to understand the thematic structure and internal organization of contemporary Arabic Applied Linguistics as a research field, using robust, quantitative, and replicable methods. Prior work either did not focus on this specific domain, misapplied Brookes’ dispersion formula, or lacked large, real-world datasets that could reliably reveal whether the field is thematically concentrated around a few dominant topics or dispersed across many sub-disciplines.
AI.method: The authors assemble a comprehensive dataset of 1,564 Arabic Applied Linguistics publications from 2019–2025 and classify them into eight core sub-disciplines (e.g., Computational Linguistics, Sociolinguistics, Language Teaching). They then correctly implement Brookes’ original Measure of Categorical Dispersion (Δ) to quantify how research output is distributed across these categories, interpreting the magnitude of Δ to assess thematic concentration versus dispersion within the field.
AI.result: The calculated dispersion index is Δ = 0.194, which is very low. This indicates that research output is spread widely across the eight sub-disciplines rather than concentrated in just one or two. Computational Linguistics emerges as the single largest subfield but does not dominate to the point of hegemony; substantial activity is also found in Sociolinguistics, Language Teaching, and other sub-disciplines, evidencing pronounced heterogeneity in thematic focus across the field.
AI.conclusion: The field of contemporary Arabic Applied Linguistics is thematically highly dispersed, characterized by strong heterogeneity and the coexistence of multiple active sub-disciplines rather than a single dominant research focus. Brookes’ Measure of Categorical Dispersion, when correctly applied, offers a powerful and replicable bibliometric tool for characterizing such disciplinary structures, and the study’s methodology can be generalized to assess thematic organization in other research domains.

title: Adversarial versification in portuguese as a jailbreak operator in LLMs
summary: Recent evidence shows that the versification of prompts constitutes a highly effective adversarial mechanism against aligned LLMs. The study 'Adversarial poetry as a universal single-turn jailbreak mechanism in large language models' demonstrates that instructions routinely refused in prose become executable when rewritten as verse, producing up to 18 x more safety failures in benchmarks derived from MLCommons AILuminate. Manually written poems reach approximately 62% ASR, and automated versions 43%, with some models surpassing 90% success in single-turn interactions. The effect is structural: systems trained with RLHF, constitutional AI, and hybrid pipelines exhibit consistent degradation under minimal semiotic formal variation. Versification displaces the prompt into sparsely supervised latent regions, revealing guardrails that are excessively dependent on surface patterns. This dissociation between apparent robustness and real vulnerability exposes deep limitations in current alignment regimes. The absence of evaluations in Portuguese, a language with high morphosyntactic complexity, a rich metric-prosodic tradition, and over 250 million speakers, constitutes a critical gap. Experimental protocols must parameterise scansion, metre, and prosodic variation to test vulnerabilities specific to Lusophone patterns, which are currently ignored.

AI.tldr: Paper shows that turning unsafe prompts into poetry can bypass safety filters in large language models, greatly increasing jailbreak success rates, and points out the need to test this specifically in Portuguese using prosodic and metrical parameters.
AI.motivation: To investigate why and how rewriting harmful or disallowed requests as verse (poetry) can systematically defeat current LLM safety mechanisms, and to highlight the lack of such evaluations in Portuguese, a major world language with specific poetic and morphosyntactic characteristics.
AI.method: The authors adapt adversarial prompts into verse form and test them as single-turn jailbreak attempts against various aligned LLMs, comparing prose vs. poetic formulations on benchmarks derived from MLCommons AILuminate, and measuring attack success rates (ASR), including both manually crafted and automatically generated poems.
AI.result: Poetic prompts dramatically increase safety failures—up to 18x more than prose—with manual poems achieving about 62% ASR and automated ones 43%, and some models exceeding 90% success in single-turn attacks; the vulnerability appears across models trained with different alignment pipelines (RLHF, constitutional AI, hybrid).
AI.conclusion: Current alignment and safety mechanisms rely too heavily on surface-form cues and are brittle to minor formal changes such as versification, which pushes prompts into poorly supervised latent regions; there is an urgent need to systematically evaluate and harden models against poetic/adversarial forms, especially in under-tested languages like Portuguese, accounting for metre, scansion, and prosodic variation.

title: Dual-Density Inference for Efficient Language Model Reasoning
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown impressive capabilities in complex reasoning tasks. However, current approaches employ uniform language density for both intermediate reasoning and final answers, leading to computational inefficiency. Our observation found that reasoning process serves a computational function for the model itself, while answering serves a communicative function for human understanding. This distinction enables the use of compressed, symbol-rich language for intermediate computations while maintaining human-readable final explanations. To address this inefficiency, we present Denser: \underline{D}ual-d\underline{ens}ity inf\underline{er}ence, a novel framework that optimizes information density separately for reasoning and answering phases. Our framework implements this through three components: a query processing module that analyzes input problems, a high-density compressed reasoning mechanism for efficient intermediate computations, and an answer generation component that translates compressed reasoning into human-readable solutions. Experimental evaluation across multiple reasoning question answering benchmarks demonstrates that Denser reduces token consumption by up to 62\% compared to standard Chain-of-Thought methods while preserving or improving accuracy. These efficiency gains are particularly significant for complex multi-step reasoning problems where traditional methods generate extensive explanations.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes Denser, a dual-density inference framework for large language models that uses compressed symbolic language for internal reasoning while keeping human-readable final answers, significantly reducing token usage without hurting accuracy.
AI.motivation: Existing LLM reasoning methods use the same verbose natural language style for both intermediate chain-of-thought and final answers, which is computationally inefficient. The authors observe that reasoning text is mainly for the model’s internal computation, whereas answers are for humans, suggesting these two stages can use different information densities.
AI.method: Denser splits inference into three modules: (1) a query processing module that analyzes the input problem; (2) a high-density, compressed reasoning representation that encodes intermediate steps in symbol-rich, compact form for efficient internal computation; and (3) an answer generation module that decodes this compressed reasoning trace back into natural, human-readable explanations.
AI.result: On multiple reasoning QA benchmarks, Denser cuts token usage by up to 62% relative to standard Chain-of-Thought prompting while maintaining or improving task accuracy, especially on complex multi-step reasoning problems.
AI.conclusion: Separating the information density of internal reasoning from that of final answers allows LLMs to perform complex reasoning more token-efficiently. Denser demonstrates that compressed, symbolic internal chains-of-thought can substantially reduce computational cost without degrading solution quality.

title: ORACLE: Time-Dependent Recursive Summary Graphs for Foresight on News Data Using LLMs
summary: ORACLE turns daily news into week-over-week, decision-ready insights for one of the Finnish University of Applied Sciences. The platform crawls and versions news, applies University-specific relevance filtering, embeds content, classifies items into PESTEL dimensions and builds a concise Time-Dependent Recursive Summary Graph (TRSG): two clustering layers summarized by an LLM and recomputed weekly. A lightweight change detector highlights what is new, removed or changed, then groups differences into themes for PESTEL-aware analysis. We detail the pipeline, discuss concrete design choices that make the system stable in production and present a curriculum-intelligence use case with an evaluation plan.

AI.tldr: ORACLE is a production-ready platform that converts daily news into weekly, PESTEL-structured, decision-ready summaries via a multi-stage NLP pipeline and change detection.
AI.motivation: Universities need a systematic way to track how external developments (e.g., political, economic, technological trends) affect curricula and strategic decisions, but raw news streams are noisy, high-volume, and hard to interpret week over week.
AI.method: The system crawls and versions news, filters them with University-specific relevance models, embeds articles, classifies them into PESTEL categories, clusters them in a Time-Dependent Recursive Summary Graph (two-layer clustering with LLM-based summarization recomputed weekly), and applies a change detector that identifies and groups new, removed, and changed items into themed, PESTEL-aware insights.
AI.result: A stable production pipeline is deployed for a Finnish University of Applied Sciences, able to automatically transform raw daily news into structured weekly insights, highlighting thematically grouped changes across PESTEL dimensions for curriculum intelligence use cases.
AI.conclusion: The paper demonstrates that a carefully engineered, multi-stage NLP and summarization pipeline can robustly turn unstructured news into actionable, week-over-week strategic insights for higher-education decision-making, and outlines an evaluation plan for curriculum-intelligence impact.

title: Toward expert-level motivational interviewing for health behavior improvement with LLMs
summary: Background: Motivational interviewing (MI) is an effective counseling approach for promoting health behavior change, but its impact is constrained by the need for highly trained human counselors. Objective: This study aimed to explore a scalable alternative by developing and evaluating Large Language Models for Motivational Interviewing (MI-LLMs). Methods: We first curated five Chinese psychological counseling corpora and, using GPT-4 with an MI-informed prompt, transcribed multi-turn dialogues from the two highest-quality datasets (CPsyCounD and PsyDTCorpus) into 2,040 MI-style counseling conversations, of which 2,000 were used for training and 40 for testing. Three Chinese-capable open-source LLMs (Baichuan2-7B-Chat, ChatGLM-4-9B-Chat and Llama-3-8B-Chinese-Chat-v2) were fine-tuned on this corpus and were named as MI-LLMs. We evaluated MI-LLMs using round-based automatic metrics and expert manual coding with the Motivational Interviewing Treatment Integrity (MITI) Coding Manual 4.2.1. Results: Across all three models, fine-tuning substantially improved BLEU-4 and ROUGE scores compared with the base models, and manual coding showed that MI-LLMs achieved technical and relational global scores, and MI-adherent ratios that approached those of real MI dialogues, although complex reflections and reflection-to-question ratios remained less frequent. Conclusions: These findings provide initial evidence that MI-oriented fine-tuning can endow general-purpose LLMs with core MI-consistent counseling behaviors, suggesting a scalable pathway toward AI-assisted health behavior change support while underscoring the need for further work on data scale, complex MI skills and real-world intervention trials.

AI.tldr: The paper fine-tunes Chinese large language models on MI-style counseling dialogues to create MI-LLMs that approximate key motivational interviewing behaviors and shows promising automatic and expert-rated performance, though advanced MI skills remain limited.
AI.motivation: Motivational interviewing is effective for health behavior change but limited by the need for highly trained human counselors, making it difficult to scale. With the rapid advancement of large language models, there is an opportunity to create AI systems that can emulate MI techniques and provide scalable, accessible counseling support, especially in Chinese, where specialized MI resources are sparse.
AI.method: The authors curated five Chinese psychological counseling corpora and selected the two highest-quality datasets (CPsyCounD and PsyDTCorpus). Using GPT-4 with an MI-informed prompt, they converted existing multi-turn dialogues into 2,040 MI-style counseling conversations. Of these, 2,000 were used to fine-tune three Chinese-capable open-source LLMs (Baichuan2-7B-Chat, ChatGLM-4-9B-Chat, Llama-3-8B-Chinese-Chat-v2), creating MI-LLMs. The remaining 40 conversations formed a test set.
